questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 1:1-20 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from condemnation to hope.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'O my people' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the vivid imagery of 'sick from head to foot' (v. 4) and 'scarlet made white as snow' (v. 18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO God addresses, WHAT they have done, WHERE this is happening (Judah), and WHY (rebellion and sin).
tips: Include the accusation of bloodshed and idolatry (v. 2-3)
Note the nation's sickness and desolation (v. 4-5)
Describe the call for repentance and the promise of restoration (v. 6-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the nation's sin (v. 2-5), the call for repentance (v. 6-7), or the promise of cleansing (v. 18-19)?
tips: The phrase 'your country lies desolate' (v. 6) powerfully shows the consequences of rebellion
The contrast of 'scarlet made white as snow' (v. 18) illustrates God's transformative mercy when repentance occurs

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah calls Judah to repent from their rebellion and idolatry to avoid destruction and experience restoration
The main point is that God's mercy is available to those who turn from sin (v. 18-20)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'scarlet made white as snow', why the nation is sick from head to foot, and the reference to Sodom?
tips: 'Scarlet made white as snow' (v. 18) is a metaphor for sin being washed away through repentance and God's mercy
The phrase 'sick from head to foot' (v. 4) describes the deep and pervasive nature of sin in the nation
Sodom (v. 10) is a city of great sin that was destroyed by God; the warning is that Judah will be destroyed if they don't repent

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to 'seek justice and defend the oppressed' (v. 17) this week?
tips: Identify one person in your community who is oppressed and take action to help them
Practice active listening and seeking justice for the marginalized

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and ask for the strength to be cleansed from sin.
tips: Ask God to remove the sin that has made you 'sick from head to foot' (v. 4)
Pray for the courage to be a voice for the oppressed (v. 17)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 2:1-12 aloud, focusing on the contrast between current idolatry and the coming peace.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'mountain' (v.2, v.3) and 'Zion' (v.2, v.3)
Pay attention to the shift from 'the mountain of the LORD' (v.2) to 'the LORD's house' (v.3)
Notice the contrast in v.5: 'the nations shall come' versus the current state of Judah in v.1-4

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO will be transformed, WHAT will happen, WHERE it will occur, and WHY Isaiah wrote this to Judah.
tips: Include that the mountain of the LORD (Zion) will be the highest mountain
Note that nations will come to Zion and the LORD will teach them
Mention the transformation of weapons into tools of peace

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the mountain of the LORD (v.2), the nations streaming to Zion (v.2-3), or the transformation of weapons (v.4-5)?
tips: The image of 'swords into plowshares' (v.4) shows the end of war and beginning of peace
The phrase 'the LORD alone shall be exalted' (v.11) declares God's sovereignty as the only focus
The contrast in v.5: 'nation shall not lift up sword against nation' reveals a complete reversal of violence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about the future of God's kingdom?
tips: Isaiah calls Judah to return to God and the true temple (Zion)
He foretells a universal kingdom where God's rule brings peace
This passage points to Christ who establishes the true mountain of God (His kingdom)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'the mountain of the LORD', the role of Judah in the coming peace, or the transformation of weapons?
tips: The 'mountain of the LORD' (v.2) refers to Zion but also symbolizes God's universal kingdom
In v.4, 'swords into plowshares' is a metaphor for the end of war but requires understanding of ancient context
The phrase 'the LORD alone shall be exalted' (v.11) implies God's sovereignty will be the only focus without diminishing human responsibility

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be part of the 'mountain of the LORD' movement this week? What step can you take to help others come to the Lord?
tips: Share the peace message with a friend in conflict
Use your gifts to build up others in community
Pray for the transformation of your heart to be like the plowshare (productive for peace)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of peace and ask for courage to be part of the mountain of the LORD.
tips: Thank God for the promise of peace through His kingdom
Ask for courage to be a peacemaker in your relationships
Pray for the nations to come to the mountain of the LORD and for weapons to become tools of peace

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 3:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the LORD's judgment and the social inversion described.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD takes away' (v.1) and the phrase 'children shall rule over them' (v.12)
Pay attention to the desperate plea in verse 13: 'You have a cloak, be our leader!'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the people of Judah) is being judged, WHAT (the LORD removes their support and causes social breakdown), WHERE (Jerusalem and Judah), and WHY (their sin and rebellion against the LORD).
tips: Include the key event: the LORD taking away bread, water, and leadership (v.1)
Note the social inversion: children as princes and infants ruling (v.12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the social inversion (v.12), the desperate plea for leadership (v.13), or the judgment on the wicked (v.15)?
tips: The image of the man grabbing his brother: 'You have a cloak, be our leader!' (v.13) shows the desperate state of the people
The phrase 'the look on their faces testifies against them' (v.15) is a strong indictment of their sin being visible
The contrast between the righteous and the wicked: 'The righteous shall be well, but woe to the wicked' (v.14) is a stark reminder of God's justice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns that Judah's sin (oppression, injustice) will lead to divine judgment and the reversal of social order
The passage emphasizes that God's judgment is just and necessary for the restoration of true order
This prophecy points to the need for repentance and the coming of Christ, the righteous leader

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The social inversion, the judgment on the leaders, or the image of the wicked being 'stumbled'?
tips: The phrase 'children shall rule over them' (v.12) is a reversal of normal social order in ancient Near Eastern societies, indicating severe judgment
The term 'stumbled' (v.15) in Hebrew (mālā) means to fall or be overturned, but here it shows that their sin has caused them to be in a state of ruin
The comparison to Sodom (v.15) refers to a city destroyed for extreme sin, so Judah is being warned of similar consequences

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of social breakdown and the need for leadership. What can you do this week to address a situation where leadership is failing in your community or in your own life?
tips: Consider a time when you've seen a lack of leadership in a group or family
Think about how you can be a leader in a small way (e.g., helping a friend, being a voice of truth)
Reflect on the warning: 'The righteous shall be well'—how can you encourage others to be righteous?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the righteous leader who will restore justice and order. Ask for strength to be a leader with integrity.
tips: Ask God to help you see the leaders in your life (family, church, community) and pray for their repentance
Thank God that He is the righteous leader who will restore justice and order
Pray for the strength to be a leader in your community with integrity

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 4:1-6 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'the Branch of the LORD', 'washed away the filth', and 'cloud by day and fire by night'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' (5 times in the passage) emphasizes divine sovereignty
The phrase 'washed away the filth' suggests a deep cleansing of sin
The contrast of 'cloud by day and fire by night' creates a vivid image of God's presence

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being saved, WHAT God is doing, WHERE this restoration happens, and WHY it matters for Judah.
tips: Include the holy remnant in Zion
Note the cleansing of Jerusalem from sin and bloodstains
Mention the Branch of the LORD as the central hope

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Branch of the LORD becoming beautiful (v.1), the washing of filth (v.3), or the cloud/fire shelter (v.4-5)?
tips: The Branch of the LORD being 'beautiful and glorious' is a powerful image of Christ's coming glory
The washing away of the filth of the daughters of Zion shows God's care for the community
The cloud and fire create a protective canopy that shields the people from harm

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about the future hope in God?
tips: This prophecy points to a future restoration where God's people will be cleansed and protected
The Branch of the LORD is Christ who will bring this restoration
It reassures Judah that God's judgment will purify and then provide a safe place for His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The 'Branch of the LORD' (who is it?), the 'washed away the filth' (what does this mean?), and the 'cloud by day and fire by night' (what is this signifying?)
tips: The 'Branch' refers to the Messiah (Christ) who will be the anointed one of God
'Washed away the filth' means the cleansing of sin and the removal of the consequences of sin
The cloud and fire represent God's presence that provides both protection and judgment

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you personally apply the theme of divine cleansing and protection this week?
tips: Ask God to help you 'wash away' your sin through confession
Pray for the cleansing of your community from the effects of sin
Seek God's protection in your daily life by trusting in His cloud and fire

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the cleansing and protection that Isaiah describes. Ask for the Branch of the LORD to come and bring hope.
tips: Thank God for the promise of cleansing from sin
Ask for the Holy Spirit to guide you into the protection of God's presence
Pray for the city of Jerusalem (and your community) to be sheltered by the cloud and fire of God's presence

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 5:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the description of the vineyard and the six woes.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'woe' (verses 5-7) and the phrase 'wild grapes' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the shift from the vineyard's expected fruit to the reality of wild grapes

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Isaiah) is addressing, WHAT (the vineyard of Judah), WHERE (the fertile hill of Judah), and WHY (the failure to produce righteousness).
tips: Include the vineyard being cleared and planted but yielding wild grapes
Note that the vineyard represents Israel, and the failure is in producing righteousness

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the vineyard description (v. 1-2), the six woes (v. 5-7), or the coming judgment (v. 8)?
tips: The phrase 'wild grapes' (v. 2) symbolizes the unfruitfulness of the people in the face of God's expectations
The repetition of 'woe' (v. 5-7) highlights the severity of the people's sins

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about their failure to produce righteousness?
tips: Isaiah is warning Judah that without true righteousness, they will face God's judgment
The vineyard parable shows that God's people (Israel) are failing to produce the fruit of righteousness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The vineyard metaphor, the meaning of 'wild grapes', or the six woes?
tips: The vineyard represents Israel, but the 'wild grapes' symbolize the unfruitfulness of the people in the context of God's expectations
The six woes (v. 5-7) are a series of warnings about specific sins that Judah has committed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of the vineyard to your life this week? Consider what you need to 'prune' to produce righteousness.
tips: Identify one area where you are 'wild grapes' (unfruitful) and seek to prune it
Ask God to help you produce righteousness in your relationships or actions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's help in producing righteousness and avoiding the judgment described.
tips: Ask God to help you recognize areas of unfruitfulness in your life
Pray for the courage to turn away from sin and embrace righteousness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 6:1-13 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'Holy, holy, holy' and the contrast between God's holiness and Isaiah's unclean lips.
tips: Notice the three times 'Holy, holy, holy' is spoken (v.2)
Pay attention to the burning coal touching Isaiah's lips (v.5)
Note the phrase 'Keep hearing but do not understand' (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Isaiah) is being commissioned, what (the message to Judah), where (the temple), and why (the need for a prophetic message).
tips: Include the vision of God's throne and seraphim
Note the cleansing of Isaiah's lips by the burning coal
Mention the commission to 'keep hearing but do not understand'

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part resonated most? Consider: the 'Holy, holy, holy' (v.2), the cleansing (v.5), or the commission (v.7)?
tips: The repetition of 'Holy, holy, holy' emphasizes God's absolute holiness
The burning coal touching Isaiah's lips shows a physical cleansing of sin
The commission to 'keep hearing but do not understand' is a radical message for the people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this vision of God's glory and his commission?
tips: The vision shows God's holiness is beyond human comprehension
The cleansing of Isaiah's lips is a call to be purified for prophetic service
The commission to make the people 'dull' is a warning against the people's spiritual blindness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The 'unclean lips', the 'burning coal from the altar', and the command to make the hearts dull?
tips: 'Unclean lips' refers to Isaiah's sinfulness and the uncleanness of the people of Judah
The burning coal from the altar points to the atonement of sin, as in the Old Testament sacrifices
The command to 'make their hearts dull' is a prophetic warning that the people will not understand the message

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Isaiah's commission to your life this week? Specifically, how can you 'keep hearing but not understand' in your own context?
tips: Consider a situation where you need to hear God's message but are not yet understanding
Think about how you can become 'unclean' in your life and need cleansing
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you hear and understand God's message

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's holiness and for cleansing in your life, and for the courage to be a messenger of the message.
tips: Thank God for the cleansing of your sins through Christ
Pray for the strength to be a messenger of God's message
Ask God to help you understand the message and to speak it with clarity

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 7:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the tension between Ahaz's fear and Isaiah's confidence.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'be careful' (v.3, v.4)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the Lord will give you a sign' (v.14)
The emotional shift from Ahaz's trembling to the promise of Immanuel (v.14-16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the house of David, Ahaz, Rezin, Pekah), WHAT (the threat of war, the sign of Immanuel), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to reassure Judah against the crisis of faith).
tips: Include the three kings: Ahaz, Rezin (Syria), Pekah (Israel)
Note the sign: the virgin conceiving and bearing Immanuel (v.14)
Ahaz's refusal to ask a sign (v.12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the sign of Immanuel (v.14), Ahaz's fear (v.3), or the phrase 'the child will not know to refuse evil' (v.16)?
tips: The phrase 'God with us' (Immanuel) is a profound promise of divine presence in the midst of crisis
Ahaz's trembling heart shows the deep fear of the people, which Isaiah addresses by offering a sign that is not of human making
The child's birth before the kings are destroyed (v.16) is a clear promise of God's victory

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: To reassure Judah that God would protect them despite the immediate threat from Syria and Israel
To show that true faith is not in human strength but in God's promise (Immanuel) which is already present in the house of David
This prophecy points to Christ as the fulfillment of the virgin birth and the promise of God being with His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The virgin birth, why the sign is given, the meaning of 'Immanuel' in this context?
tips: The term 'virgin' in ancient Hebrew (almah) refers to a young woman who is not yet married, not a virgin in the modern sense
The sign of Immanuel is given because Ahaz was in crisis and needed a tangible promise that God would act on his behalf
'Immanuel' means 'God with us' - a promise that God is present in the midst of the crisis, not a future event

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God being with you in a time of crisis this week?
tips: Identify a current crisis (like financial, relational, or health) and pray for God's presence as Immanuel
Practice listening for God's voice in the midst of your crisis, as Isaiah did with Ahaz
Commit to trusting God's provision even when it seems impossible

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being with you in your crisis. Ask for the courage to trust His promise.
tips: Thank God for the promise of Immanuel - God with us in your crisis
Ask for the strength to be like Ahaz, who needed a sign but refused to test God
Pray for the courage to trust God's provision when the situation seems hopeless

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 8:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the prophecy of the child (verse 2) and the Assyrian flood (verses 4-5).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Maher-shalal-hash-baz' (verse 1) as a prophetic sign
The emotional tone shifts from hope (the child) to warning (the flood) in verses 4-5
The phrase 'O Immanuel' (verse 5) is a key term for the coming Messiah

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned (the people of Judah), WHAT happens (the Assyrian invasion), WHERE it occurs (Judah), and WHY (because they refused the water of Shiloah).
tips: Include the sign-child (the son born to Isaiah and the prophetess)
Note the two outcomes: the swift spoil (Assyria) and the flood of the Euphrates
The reason: the people's refusal of the gentle waters of Shiloah (a symbol of God's provision)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the sign-child (verse 2), the Assyrian flood (verses 4-5), or the stone of stumbling (verse 9).
tips: The sign-child: a child born to Isaiah and the prophetess who will be a symbol of the coming invasion (before he can speak)
The flood of the Euphrates: a powerful image of God's judgment that will sweep into Judah and rise to the neck
The stone of stumbling: God's promise as both sanctuary and a stumbling block for those who reject Him

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Assyria (the enemy) will invade because they have turned away from God's gentle provision (the waters of Shiloah)
God is with them (verse 7) and they should fear the LORD of hosts (verse 8), not the Assyrian threat
The passage also points to Christ as the sanctuary (Immanuel) and the stone of stumbling for those who reject Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The sign-child, the flood of the Euphrates, and the stone of stumbling.
tips: The sign-child: Isaiah's son is a sign that the invasion will happen quickly (before he can speak) - it's a prophetic sign
The flood of the Euphrates: Assyria's invasion is depicted as a flood that will rise to the neck of Judah, not a complete destruction
The stone of stumbling: In Christian theology, Christ is the stone that some reject (1 Peter 2:8), but here it's a warning to Judah that they might reject God's protection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the warning about Assyria (the enemy) apply to today? What can you do to be like the 'water of Shiloah' (God's gentle provision) in your life?
tips: Pray for God's protection in the face of current threats (like political or social issues)
Surrender your anxieties to God, trusting that He is your sanctuary (verse 7)
Share the 'testimony' (verse 10) with others by being a seal of God's teaching

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His protection and ask for courage to trust Him in the face of adversity.
tips: Thank God for being the sanctuary (Immanuel) for those who trust Him
Pray for strength to avoid the stone of stumbling (rejection of God) by focusing on His presence
Ask God to help you not fear what others fear (verse 7)

chapters.chapterTitle: For Unto Us a Child Is Born

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 9:1-7 aloud, paying attention to the phrases describing light, the child, and the divine names.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'light' (twice in verse 1) and the contrast with darkness
Pay attention to the four divine names: Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace
The phrase 'for unto us a child is born' is the opening of the passage and sets the tone

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is the focus, WHAT the child brings, WHERE this light dawns, and WHY it matters for Judah.
tips: Include the contrast between the former time (Zebulun and Naphtali) and the latter time (Galilee of the nations)
Note the transformation from darkness to light for the people
The child's role as the one who will bring government and peace

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the light dawning in darkness (v.1-2), the divine names of the child (v.6), or the end of the government and peace (v.7)?
tips: The phrase 'the people walking in darkness have seen a great light' is vivid and contrasts the current state of Judah with the future hope
The four divine names (Wonderful Counselor, etc.) reveal the full nature of the child who will rule
The promise of 'no end' to the government and peace shows the eternal kingdom

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about the child born to them?
tips: Isaiah was foretelling the birth of a child who would bring light and peace to a nation that had been in darkness (Judah)
The child is the one who will rule forever on David's throne, fulfilling the promise of a lasting kingdom
This passage is a prophetic announcement that God is bringing hope and restoration to His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The divine names, the concept of the child ruling, or the contrast between past and present?
tips: The four divine names (Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace) are a unique way to describe Christ and are not typical of human rulers
The phrase 'the government shall be upon His shoulder' (v.6) might be confusing because it's a metaphor for leadership, not literal physical burden
The phrase 'Galilee of the nations' (v.2) refers to a region that was historically overlooked, which is a sign of God's global impact

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of light dawning in darkness to your current situation?
tips: Identify a place in your life where you feel 'in darkness' and ask how the light of Christ (the child) can bring hope
Pray for the strength to be a 'light' to others in your community
Reflect on how the child's government and peace can be a model for your relationships this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the light that dawns in your darkness and ask for the child's peace to transform your life.
tips: Thank God for the promise of the child who brings peace and government to His people
Pray for the courage to see God's light in your current circumstances
Ask God to help you become a part of the 'way of the sea, Galilee of the nations' where His light shines

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Isaiah 10 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 11:1-10 aloud, focusing on the imagery of the shoot from Jesse and the Spirit of the LORD.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the shoot from Jesse's stump' (v1) - the broken lineage becoming a source of hope
Pay attention to the sevenfold Spirit (v2) - wisdom, understanding, counsel, might, knowledge, and fear of the LORD
Note the promise of peace: 'the wolf shall dwell with the lamb' (v6) - a sign of the restored creation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO this shoot will be, WHAT he will do, WHERE this kingdom will be established, and WHY God chose Jesse's line.
tips: Include that the shoot comes from the stump of Jesse (the broken Davidic line)
Note the anointing with the sevenfold Spirit of the LORD
Describe the peaceable kingdom where the wolf and lamb dwell together

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Spirit of the LORD resting on Him (v2), the wolf and lamb living together (v6), or the root of Jesse as a signal for the peoples (v10).
tips: The sevenfold Spirit (v2) shows the fullness of God's blessing on the Messiah
The wolf and lamb living together (v6) is a powerful image of the end of violence and the restoration of creation
The root of Jesse standing as a signal for the peoples (v10) shows that this ruler will be known by all nations

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about God's plan for restoration through the shoot from Jesse?
tips: Isaiah was addressing Judah's need for hope after their exile and the broken covenant
The passage promises a righteous king who will bring peace and justice, restoring the relationship between God and creation
This is a foreshadowing of the Messiah who will establish a kingdom of peace

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'stump' in Jesse's line, the sevenfold Spirit, and the image of peace in a violent world.
tips: 'Stump' refers to the remnant of Jesse's lineage that was broken (like the Davidic line after the exile), but God will bring forth a shoot from it
The sevenfold Spirit (wisdom, understanding, etc.) is a unique gift for the Messiah that shows his full authority and completeness
The wolf and lamb living together is a sign of the coming peace that will only be fully realized in the kingdom of the Messiah, not in the current world

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a part of the peaceable kingdom by reflecting on the Messiah's coming and the restoration of creation?
tips: This week, reach out to someone who is angry or hurt and seek reconciliation
Pray for the nations to come to know the Lord as the shoot from Jesse's stump brings hope to the world
Practice being a peacemaker in your community by showing kindness to those who are different from you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the promise of peace through the shoot from Jesse. Ask for the courage to be a peacemaker and to seek the Lord.
tips: Thank God for the Messiah who will bring peace to all nations
Pray for the strength to be a peacemaker in a divided world
Ask God to help you see the root of Jesse (the Messiah) as the signal for the peoples to seek Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 12:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the declaration of thanksgiving and the repeated phrases of trust.
tips: Notice the phrase 'In that day you will say' (v.1) - a future time of salvation
Pay attention to 'Your anger turned away' (v.1) - a key phrase of God's change of heart
Notice the well of salvation (v.3) - a metaphor for abundant life

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who (the people of Judah) is experiencing what (God turning away His anger and becoming their salvation), where (in the context of the day of redemption), and why (to give thanks and trust in God).
tips: The people of Judah are the ones declaring thanksgiving after a period of judgment
The 'day' refers to the time when God's anger has turned away and His mercy has come
The wells of salvation (v.3) are the source of life that the people will draw from

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the personal declaration of trust (v.2), the wells of salvation (v.3), or the Holy One of Israel (v.6).
tips: The phrase 'Your anger turned away' (v.1) is powerful because it shows God's change of heart in the midst of a people who have experienced judgment
The well of salvation (v.3) is a strong metaphor for the life-giving presence of God that the people will actively draw from
The Holy One of Israel (v.6) emphasizes God's presence and active involvement in the community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is calling Judah to a place of gratitude and trust after a period of divine judgment (the Assyrian invasion and exile)
The main point is that God has turned away His anger and has become the salvation for His people, so they should give thanks and proclaim His name
This passage foreshadows the coming of the Messiah who is the ultimate salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to 'in that day' (v.1), the metaphor of 'wells of salvation' (v.3), and the title 'Holy One of Israel' (v.6).
tips: 'In that day' refers to a specific future time of salvation after God's judgment has passed (as in the context of the book of Isaiah)
'Wells of salvation' is a metaphor for the abundant life and provision that comes from God (as in John 4:14)
The 'Holy One of Israel' is a title for God that emphasizes His holiness and presence among His people (as in the Old Testament)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, draw from the 'wells of salvation' (v.3) by identifying one area where you need to trust God's provision instead of your own fears.
tips: Reflect on a time when God turned away His anger from you (v.1)
Practice thanking God for the wells of salvation that flow from Him
Share the message of salvation with others this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He has turned away His anger and provided salvation for you.
tips: Thank God for the wells of salvation that flow from Him (v.3)
Ask for the Holy One of Israel to dwell in your midst (v.6)
Pray for courage to proclaim His name and make known His deeds among the peoples

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 13:1-22 aloud, focusing on the warnings about Babylon's destruction and the cosmic signs.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' and the phrase 'wail' (v. 1) to emphasize urgency
Pay attention to the cosmic imagery: 'the stars will not give their light, the sun will be dark' (v. 10)
Note the shift from judgment on Babylon to its complete destruction (vv. 17-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is warned, WHAT will happen, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Babylon falls.
tips: Include the three key elements: God's judgment on Babylon, the cosmic disturbance, and the destruction of all worldly power
Note that Babylon is described as 'the glory of kingdoms' (v. 22) and will be destroyed like Sodom and Gomorrah
The warning is given to Judah to avoid being caught in the destruction

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the cosmic signs (v. 10), Babylon's destruction (v. 22), or the call to 'wail' (v. 1).
tips: The comparison of Babylon to Sodom and Gomorrah (v. 22) is devastating and shows total destruction
The phrase 'the stars will not give their light' (v. 10) is a sign of the day of the LORD that affects the entire universe
The call to 'wail' (v. 1) is a urgent cry for the people to prepare for the coming judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this oracle about Babylon's fall?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Babylon, a powerful enemy, will be destroyed by God's judgment
This serves as a reminder that God is sovereign and that no worldly power can stand against Him
The message is that the true kingdom of God is beyond Babylon's influence

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand? The day of the LORD, Babylon's identity, or the cosmic signs?
tips: 'The day of the LORD' (v. 1) refers to God's judgment that will be visible and catastrophic, not the day of the Lord's kingdom
Babylon in this context represents all worldly powers that oppose God (e.g., the Roman Empire, modern systems of sin and idolatry)
The cosmic signs (e.g., stars not shining) are a sign of God's judgment that affects the entire universe

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning about Babylon's fall to your life this week?
tips: Identify a 'Babylon' in your life (e.g., a system of sin, an idol, or worldly success) that you need to let go of
Reflect on the call to 'wail' (v. 1) - when you feel God's judgment is near, how can you respond with repentance?
Pray for the courage to stand against false systems that oppose God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the coming judgment on Babylon and its implications for our lives.
tips: Thank God that He is the ultimate judge and that Babylon (all worldly powers) will fall
Ask for the courage to stand against the false systems that oppose God
Pray for the church to be warned and to turn from Babylon-like systems

chapters.chapterTitle: The Fall of the King of Babylon

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 14:1-27 aloud, focusing on the king's declaration of pride (verses 12-14) and his fall (verses 15-17).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'how you are fallen' (v.15) and the king's original boast (v.13)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the king of Babylon is, WHAT he did (taunting God), WHERE his pride was (heavenly realm), and WHY God will bring him down (his pride against God).
tips: Include the king's claim to sit above the stars (v.13)
Note the shift from his exalted position to Sheol (v.15)
Mention God's purpose: to judge the proud and establish His kingdom

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the king's prideful declaration (v.13), his fall to Sheol (v.15), or God's promise of judgment (v.27).
tips: The king's boast: 'I will make myself like the Most High' shows total defiance of God
The contrast between his high place and his lowly end in Sheol is powerful
God's final statement: 'As I have planned, so shall it be' emphasizes His sovereign control

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this prophecy about the king of Babylon?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Babylon's pride will be destroyed, but also reminds them that God's purpose for Israel (rest and restoration) will be fulfilled
The prophecy shows that God's judgment on the proud (Babylon) is part of His plan for His people
This prophecy is a reminder that no one can exalt themselves above God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The king of Babylon as the 'Day Star' (v.12), the meaning of 'Sheol' (v.15), and the connection to Christ.
tips: 'Day Star' (v.12) is a title for the king of Babylon, but in Hebrew it also refers to the morning star (a star that rises early), symbolizing his exalted status
Sheol (v.15) is the grave, not the hell of Christian theology, but the place of the dead
The Christ connection: The king of Babylon typifies all who exalt themselves against God, and Christ is the true Morning Star (Rev 22:16) who conquered through the cross

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the warning about pride in Isaiah 14 apply to your life this week? What action can you take to avoid exalting yourself above God?
tips: Reflect on a time when you felt proud or exalted (e.g., in your work, relationships, or spiritual life)
Ask God to humble you in areas where you feel you are the center of attention
Choose one small step to lower your pride this week (e.g., admit a mistake, serve someone without expecting recognition)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on pride and ask for humility.
tips: Thank God that He knows the heart of the proud and will bring them to their knees
Pray for the courage to humble yourself when pride rises
Ask God to help you see that your true identity is in Him, not in your own achievements

tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary

Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit

Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point

tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly
