Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 16:1-16 aloud, focusing on the emotional lament and the repeated phrases about Moab's pride and the call for refuge.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'pride' (v. 3, 4, 5) and the phrase 'Moab wail for Moab' (v. 5)
Pay attention to the emotional tone: 'My heart moans like a lyre' (v. 4) shows deep sorrow
The phrase 'the glory of Moab will be brought into contempt' (v. 5) is a strong prediction of downfall

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: Who is being addressed? What does God command? Where does this happen? When? Why does this happen?
tips: Include the daughters of Moab being 'like fleeing birds' (v. 1)
Note the call for Judah to shelter Moab's outcasts (v. 3)
Mention the three-year timeframe for Moab's downfall (v. 5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call for refuge (v. 3), the lament for Moab (v. 5), or the heart's lament (v. 4)?
tips: The phrase 'make your shade like night at noon' (v. 3) creates a vivid image of protection in the midst of judgment
The self-referential lament 'Moab wail for Moab' (v. 5) shows the depth of Moab's impending destruction
The heart moaning like a lyre (v. 4) conveys the emotional weight of the prophecy

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about Moab and their own identity as a people?
tips: Isaiah is warning Judah that Moab's pride will lead to their destruction (v. 5)
He calls Judah to be a refuge for Moab's outcasts, showing God's mercy to the oppressed
The Davidic throne (v. 5) is a promise of God's faithful rule that will protect and judge righteously

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of Moab's condition, the throne imagery, or the prophecy of Moab's downfall?
tips: The 'fords of the Arnon' (v. 1) are river crossings in Moab, a common place for trade and conflict
The 'throne of steadfast love' (v. 5) refers to God's covenant rule through David (a promise of the Messiah)
Moab's pride is condemned because they were haughty and unyielding (as seen in the context of the surrounding nations)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a refuge for someone in your community this week, as Judah was called to be for Moab's outcasts?
tips: Identify one person who is feeling abandoned or in need of shelter
Pray for them and offer practical help (like listening or providing a safe space)
Consider how your actions today can reflect God's mercy to the outcast

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His mercy and ask for courage to be a refuge for the outcasts in your community.
tips: Thank God for the promise of the Davidic throne (v. 5) that He is faithful and just
Pray for the courage to shelter those who are vulnerable
Ask God to help you see the outcasts in your life and be a refuge for them

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 17:1-12 aloud, focusing on the strong declarations of destruction and the imagery of the remnant.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Behold, Damascus will cease to be a city' (v1) - a direct and immediate judgment
Pay attention to the contrast between the destruction of Damascus and the small remnant of Syria (v4)
The phrase 'gleanings will be left, like two or three berries' (v5) - a vivid image of minimal but meaningful harvest

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT happens, WHERE (geographically), and WHY (the cause of destruction).
tips: Damascus is destroyed as a city and kingdom (v1-2)
The remnant of Syria is a small group (like a few berries) in contrast to the former glory (v4)
The destruction occurs because the people have forgotten God and turned to foreign gods (v12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider the imagery of gleanings (v5), the turning to the Maker (v8), or the rejection of altars (v8).
tips: The olive tree imagery (v5) is universal and relatable - it speaks to God's faithfulness even in scarcity
The shift from altars to the Holy One of Israel (v8) is a profound spiritual change that resonates with anyone who has experienced idolatry
The phrase 'man will look to his Maker' (v8) points to a day when people will turn to God in genuine need

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that if they follow the pattern of Damascus (turning from God), they will face similar judgment
The passage emphasizes that God will leave a small remnant who will turn to Him
This is a call to remember God as the true Maker and not to rely on false gods

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to Syria, the meaning of 'gleanings', and the identity of the 'Holy One of Israel'.
tips: Syria is used here as a symbol of nations that have turned away from God (not a specific place in this context)
Gleanings (v5) refers to a small, intentional harvest left by the farmer for the poor - here it represents the small remnant of God's people
The Holy One of Israel (v8) is God the Father as the covenant God of Israel; in Christian theology, this title points to Jesus as the fulfillment of the promise

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of turning to the Maker in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are relying on your own efforts (like altars) instead of God
Pray to look to the Holy One of Israel (God) in a specific situation this week
Practice being a 'gleaner' - seek God's provision in small but meaningful ways

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for the courage to turn to Him.
tips: Thank God for leaving a remnant (the two or three berries) for His purposes
Pray for the strength to look to the Holy One of Israel when life is difficult
Ask God to help you become part of the small but precious remnant

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 18:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the description of Cush and the imagery of God watching.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Cush' as the land beyond the rivers
Pay attention to the phrase 'quietly look from My dwelling' which emphasizes God's silent observation
The phrase 'rivers divide' in verse 10 is a key geographical marker

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is addressed, WHAT God commands, WHERE the judgment occurs, and WHY nations will bring tribute to Zion.
tips: Cush is the nation that will eventually bring tribute to Zion
The judgment on Cush happens before the harvest (a time of growth)
The tribute comes after God's pruning of the shoots

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's silent watching (v. 10), the imagery of the cutting off of shoots (v. 10), or the tribute from Cush (v. 24)?
tips: The phrase 'I will quietly look from My dwelling' (v. 10) shows God's active yet hidden presence
The metaphor of 'cutting off the shoots with pruning hooks' (v. 10) illustrates God's judgment that is precise and necessary
The promise that Cush will bring tribute to Zion (v. 24) is a hopeful conclusion after judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about God's sovereignty over distant nations?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that even distant nations (Cush) will one day bring tribute to Zion, showing God's universal rule
This prophecy points to the future where all nations will come to Christ (the ultimate tribute)
The timing of judgment is for the purpose of bringing the nations to the knowledge of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'Cush', the timing of judgment, and the concept of 'tribute'?
tips: Cush in ancient contexts was a region south of Egypt, but in Isaiah it represents a distant nation that will eventually be brought into God's kingdom
The phrase 'before the harvest' (v. 10) refers to a time of growth that is about to be cut off, not the harvest itself
Tribute in this context is not a tax but a voluntary offering to God, as seen in the Christ connection (Acts 8)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be part of the 'tribute' that brings nations to Christ this week?
tips: Think about how you can be a 'Cushite' (a person from a distant land) who is now part of the body of Christ
Pray that God will open your heart to be a channel of tribute for others
Offer your life as a tribute to Christ, especially when you are in a place of judgment

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray that God will use you to bring nations to Christ, just as Cush will bring tribute to Zion.
tips: Thank God for the promise that all nations will come to Him
Pray for courage to be a bridge for nations in a divided world
Ask God to help you to be a place of tribute to Him this week

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 19:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Egypt's idolatry and the LORD's coming on a cloud.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'in that day' (v. 12, 13, 20) which marks the turning point
Pay attention to the phrase 'the LORD is riding on a swift cloud' (v. 9) evoking divine power
Note the emotional shift from Egypt's confusion (v. 1-8) to the blessing of the nations (v. 23-25)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY (the LORD's purpose) in this oracle.
tips: The LORD's coming to Egypt and the shaking of idols (v. 1-8)
The turning of Egypt into a land of confusion and the building of an altar to the LORD (v. 12)
The blessing of Egypt, Assyria, and Israel as a trinity of nations (v. 23-25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the LORD's coming on a cloud (v. 9), the trembling of idols (v. 1-8), or the altar in Egypt (v. 12)?
tips: The phrase 'Egypt will be like women, trembling before the hand of the LORD' (v. 12) is a vivid image of complete submission and fear
The promise of an altar in Egypt (v. 12) shows the ultimate reversal of Egypt's idolatry to worship of the one true God
The declaration that Egypt will be 'a third with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth' (v. 23) is a powerful hope for the future

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this oracle against Egypt?
tips: Isaiah is warning Judah that Egypt's idolatry will be destroyed and that the LORD will bring a new order where Egypt becomes a place of worship and blessing
This oracle shows that God's plan includes even Egypt (a powerful enemy of Judah) in His redemptive work
The main point is that God will use the fall of Egypt to bring about a new covenant where nations are blessed through His presence

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Egypt in God's plan, the meaning of 'a hard master', or the connection to Christ?
tips: The phrase 'a hard master' (v. 14) refers to a harsh ruler who will dominate Egypt, but it's not a divine punishment—it's God's judgment that will lead to a new order

The term 'combed flax' (v. 14) is a specific agricultural term for a type of flax that is processed for weaving, which was a key industry in Egypt. Its destruction symbolizes the collapse of Egypt's e
The connection to Christ: Isaiah prophesies that Christ will sojourn in Egypt (Matt 2:15) and that His gospel will spread to Egypt and the entire world (v. 23-25)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's judgment on Egypt and blessing for all nations to your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are 'combed flax' (v. 14) in your life—something that is being destroyed by the world but needs to be renewed in Christ
Pray for the courage to be a blessing to others in your community, as Egypt will be a blessing to the world (v. 23)
Ask God to help you trust that He will provide for you even when you are in a 'hard master' situation (v. 14)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the theme of Egypt's transformation and the blessing of nations.
tips: Thank God that He turns the nations of the world to worship Him
Pray for the nations of the world (especially Egypt) to experience the LORD's presence and blessing
Ask God to help you be part of the blessing that flows from His kingdom

chapters.chapterTitle: A Sign Against Egypt and Cush

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 20:1-6 aloud, paying attention to the description of Isaiah's sign and the consequences for Egypt and Cush.
tips: Notice the phrase 'loose the sackcloth from your waist and take off your sandals from your feet' (v. 1) - this is the immediate action
The three-year duration (v. 3) is a specific time frame for the sign
The phrase 'naked and barefoot' (v. 5) appears multiple times to emphasize shame

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the prophet is, WHAT the sign is, WHERE it happens (as a sign against Egypt and Cush), and WHY it is done (to expose false hope in Egypt and Cush).
tips: Isaiah walks naked and barefoot for three years as a sign (v. 3)
The Assyrian king will lead away Egyptian captives and Cushite exiles (v. 5)
The inhabitants of the coastland (Egypt and Cush) will be dismayed and ashamed (v. 6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Isaiah's three-year sign (v. 3), the Assyrian king's action (v. 5), or the inhabitants' question (v. 6)?
tips: The three-year sign shows enduring humility and shame (a sign of God's judgment on Egypt and Cush)
The Assyrian king taking the captives naked and barefoot (v. 5) is a public humiliation that will shame Egypt
The inhabitants' question: 'How then can we escape?' (v. 6) reveals the hopelessness of their situation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about their false hope in Egypt and Cush?
tips: Judah's trust in Egypt and Cush as their refuge from Assyrian threat will be exposed as false
The Assyrian king will take the captives and shame them, showing that no one can escape God's judgment
This prophecy serves as a warning that false hopes lead to shame and destruction

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The sign of three years, the meaning of 'Cush', and the Assyrian conquest?
tips: The three-year sign is a prophetic image, not literal. It represents the duration of the shame that will befall Egypt and Cush.
'Cush' in ancient Hebrew refers to the land of Ethiopia and the southern nations, but in this context, it's used to represent Egypt's allies and the southern kingdoms.

The Assyrian king (Sargon) is the one who will lead away the captives (v. 5), but note that this prophecy was given in the time of the Assyrian threat to Judah, so it's a future event for Egypt and Cu

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of false hope and no escape to your life this week? Consider a situation where you have placed hope in something that is not God.
tips: Identify one area where you have false hope (e.g., a person, a plan, or a nation)
Pray for God to expose that false hope and lead you to trust Him instead
Like the captives, be willing to face the shame of your false hope and accept God's provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that false hopes lead to shame, and ask for the courage to face the truth of His provision.
tips: Thank God for His truth that no one can escape His judgment when they trust in false hopes
Pray for the courage to face the shame of our own false hopes
Ask God to help us not to turn to Egypt or Cush (false hopes) but to trust in Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 21:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'Fallen, fallen is Babylon' in verse 9 and the watchman's urgent declaration.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'fallen' in verse 9: 'Fallen, fallen is Babylon'
Pay attention to the watchman's role and his urgent declaration in verses 1-2
The phrase 'carved images of her gods lie shattered' (v.9) is a powerful image of destruction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is observing, WHAT is happening, WHERE it occurs, and WHY the watchman is announcing this.
tips: The watchman sees riders from Media and Elam (v.1-2)
Babylon's fall is announced as a result of God's judgment (v.9)
The shattered gods symbolize the end of Babylon's false power

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the watchman's declaration of Babylon's fall (v.9), the imagery of shattered gods (v.9), or the call for Media and Elam to attack (v.1-2).
tips: The phrase 'Fallen, fallen is Babylon' (v.9) is a powerful and repeated declaration of judgment
The image of 'carved images of her gods lie shattered' (v.9) shows the complete destruction of Babylon's false religion
The watchman's role as a messenger (v.1-2) highlights God's use of human agents to deliver judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Babylon, a powerful enemy, will fall due to God's judgment
This prophecy shows that God's sovereignty extends over all nations, including Babylon
It foreshadows the ultimate fall of all false powers (as in Revelation 18)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'the wilderness of the sea', the role of Media and Elam, and the phrase 'the traitor betrays, the destroyer destroys'?
tips: 'Wilderness of the sea' likely refers to a region near the sea that was a route to Babylon (historical context)
Media and Elam were ancient kingdoms that were enemies of Babylon but here are called to attack it as part of God's plan
'The traitor betrays' might refer to Babylon as a traitor to God's covenant with Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Babylon's fall teaches that worldly powers are temporary. What area of your life requires you to let go of false power and trust God's provision this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are relying on human systems (like Babylon) for security
Practice surrender by sharing that area with God in prayer
Read Isaiah 21:9 and meditate on the destruction of false power

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the fall of Babylon and ask for courage to see the temporary nature of worldly power.
tips: Thank God that He brings judgment on the powers that oppose Him
Pray for wisdom to avoid the pitfalls of Babylon (worldly power and false idols)
Ask God to help you trust Him in areas where you feel insecure

chapters.chapterTitle: Oracle Concerning the Valley of Vision

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 22:1-22 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'valley of vision', 'slain are not slain', and 'key of David'.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the valley of vision' as a place of deception
Pay attention to the lament: 'I weep bitterly; do not labor to comfort me'
Listen for the contrast between self-reliance and God's authority

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: Who is failing, what is happening, where is it occurring, and why is it happening in Judah?
tips: Include the city of David and the valley of vision as key locations
Note that Shebna the steward is condemned and Eliakim receives the key of David
Mention that the leaders have fled and the city is in danger

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the valley of vision (v.1), Shebna's condemnation (v.12), or the key of David (v.22)?
tips: The valley of vision represents the false visions and self-deception that lead to destruction
Shebna's condemnation shows the failure of the current leadership
The key of David is a promise of God's restoration through a true steward

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about their leadership and the future of God's kingdom?
tips: Isaiah warns that Judah's self-reliance will lead to destruction but promises restoration through God's true steward
The key of David points to Christ as the ultimate ruler who will restore God's house
This passage shows that God's authority will be maintained through faithful leadership

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging to understand? The valley of vision, Shebna's role, or the key of David?
tips: The valley of vision is a metaphor for the false teachings and self-deception that lead to destruction in Judah
Shebna was a high-ranking official in the temple (the steward of the house of God) but has become corrupt
The key of David represents the authority to open and close the gates of the temple, which Christ holds (as in Revelation 3:7)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's true steward to your life this week? Be specific about a situation where you are relying on your own leadership.
tips: Identify a leadership role you hold where you might be relying on your own strength
Ask God for the key of David to open the gates of your life to His authority
Pray for the courage to step away from false leadership and follow the true steward

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the valley of vision and the need for true leadership in your life.
tips: Thank God for the promise of the key of David (the true steward)
Ask for the strength to see the valley of vision (false teachings) and not fall into it
Pray for a heart that trusts God's leadership rather than self-reliance

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 23:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the lamentation in verses 1 and 3, and the divine judgment in verses 11-12.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'wail' (v1) as a call to lamentation
Pay attention to the contrast between Tyre's past glory and its future destruction (v9-12)
Note the phrase 'the LORD of hosts' (v11) as a strong declaration of God's authority

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is being judged (Tyre), WHAT happens to Tyre, WHERE it occurs (the city of Tyre and the surrounding sea), and WHY the LORD is doing it (to defile the pride of Tyre's glory).
tips: Include that Tyre was a major trading center (marketplace of nations)
Note the destruction of Tyre's harbor and houses (v1)
Highlight the judgment as a result of Tyre's arrogance and pride (v11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the grain of Shihor (v4), the defilement of pride (v11), or the seventy years (v12).
tips: The grain of Shihor illustrates Tyre's historical role in trade, showing how deeply it was embedded in the ancient economy
The phrase 'pompous pride of all glory' (v11) is a powerful image of the city's arrogance being destroyed by God
The seventy years (v12) points to a future time when Tyre's wealth will be dedicated to the LORD, which foreshadows the New Covenant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about the judgment on Tyre?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Tyre's wealth and trade will be destroyed because of its pride and arrogance
This judgment shows that God's kingdom will eventually take over all nations, including the wealth of Tyre
The passage emphasizes that even the most powerful cities are under God's sovereignty and will be used for His purposes

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The grain of Shihor, the term 'LORD of hosts', and the seventy years?
tips: Shihor was a river in Egypt that was part of the trade route to the Mediterranean; Tyre controlled the grain trade from this river
'LORD of hosts' refers to God as the commander of the heavenly armies, emphasizing His sovereignty over all creation
The seventy years in this context refers to the time when Tyre would be destroyed and its wealth dedicated to the LORD, which is a sign of God's ultimate sovereignty

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you dedicate a part of your wealth or resources to God this week, as a response to Tyre's judgment?
tips: Consider giving a specific amount of money or time to a charitable cause that aligns with God's kingdom
Reflect on an area where you feel proud and ask God to humble you
Practice sharing your resources with others, as Tyre's wealth was meant to be dedicated to the LORD

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on Tyre and ask for humility in your pride.
tips: Thank God for His sovereignty over all nations and for using even Tyre's wealth for His purposes
Ask for courage to surrender your pride and for the strength to dedicate your resources to God
Pray for a heart that recognizes God as the ultimate provider, not the wealth of the world

chapters.chapterTitle: The LORD's Devastation of the Earth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 24:1-13 aloud, focusing on the description of the earth's desolation and the contrast between judgment and glory.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the earth' (6 times) to emphasize global impact
Pay attention to the emotional shift from desolation (v.1-5) to hope in the Righteous One (v.11)
Listen for the contrast between the curse (v.7) and the songs of praise (v.11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who the LORD is doing, what He is doing to the earth, where this devastation occurs, and why it happens (based on the broken covenant).
tips: Include the earth's desolation and the scattering of inhabitants (v.1-2)
Note the specific groups affected: priest, people, master and servant (v.3)
Highlight the cause: transgressed laws and broken covenant (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this chapter stood out most? Consider the earth's desolation (v.1-5), the curse on the earth (v.7), or the glory to the Righteous One (v.11).
tips: The phrase 'the earth lies defiled under its inhabitants' (v.6) shows the deep consequence of sin on the created order
The sudden shift to 'Glory to the Righteous One' (v.11) offers hope despite the devastation
The warning of 'terror and pit and snare' (v.12) underscores the immediacy of God's judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about the coming judgment and hope?
tips: The judgment is a response to Judah's unfaithfulness in the covenant (v.6)
The glory to the Righteous One (Christ) is the hope that comes after judgment
This passage points to the ultimate restoration through Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to understand? Focus on cultural context, terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The phrase 'the everlasting covenant' (v.6) refers to the covenant between God and Israel, broken by idolatry and sin
The term 'despoiled' (v.4) implies complete ruin, not just temporary damage
How can the earth's desolation (v.1-5) be reconciled with the hope of restoration in Christ (v.11)?

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge you to live differently this week? Focus on the theme of broken covenant and the need for restoration.
tips: Identify one area where your actions have contributed to the 'defilement' of the earth (v.6)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you break away from sin and embrace the restoration through Christ
This week, share the hope of 'Glory to the Righteous One' with someone who is struggling

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the devastation of the earth and the hope in the Righteous One.
tips: Thank God for the judgment that exposes sin and the hope of restoration through Christ
Pray for courage to face the 'terror and pit and snare' (v.12) by trusting in the Righteous One
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help us live in a way that does not defile the earth (v.6)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 25:1-9 aloud, focusing on the contrast between destruction and restoration.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'O LORD' (v1) and the contrast between destruction (v2) and restoration (v5-7)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from lament (v2) to hope (v8-9)
The phrase 'swallow up death forever' (v7) is a powerful image of final victory

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (delivers and establishes a feast of victory), WHERE (on this mountain), and WHY (to bring salvation and restoration to all peoples).
tips: Include God's deliverance from destruction (v2) and His role as protector for the poor (v4)
Note the feast is for all peoples (v5) and the removal of death and tears (v7,8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the feast of rich food (v5), 'swallow up death forever' (v7), or 'wipe away tears' (v7).
tips: The feast of rich food and well-aged wine (v5) symbolizes abundant provision for all peoples
'Swallow up death forever' (v7) promises eternal victory over death, echoing Christ's resurrection
'Wipe away tears from all faces' (v7) represents the end of suffering and universal healing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah addresses Judah after their destruction, promising a future restoration where God's victory will be celebrated by all nations
The passage emphasizes God as the ultimate deliverer who has already begun the work of setting aside death and tears
This passage foreshadows the ultimate victory of Christ in the New Covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphors of 'swallow up' and 'veil', and the promise of wiping tears.
tips: 'Swallow up' (v6-7) means the complete removal of the covering (oppression) and death, not a temporary action
The 'covering that is cast over all peoples' (v6) refers to the spiritual and political oppression (like Babylonian rule)
The 'wiping away tears' (v7) is a promise of the end of suffering, fulfilled in Christ's resurrection and return

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you experience the hope of God's victory feast this week? Focus on the wiping away of tears and the feast for all peoples.
tips: Share the hope of this feast with someone who is grieving (as a tangible expression of the wiping of tears)
Practice gratitude for God's deliverance in your life (like the feast of rich food)
Join a community of believers to celebrate God's salvation together

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of swallowing up death and wiping away tears. Ask for the feast of victory to break into your life.
tips: Thank God for the promise of swallowing up death and wiping tears (v7)
Ask for the courage to share the feast (v5) with others in distress
Pray for unity among all peoples to celebrate God's salvation (v8)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 26:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'the LORD' and the contrast between the 'city of salvation' and the 'dust'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' (7 times in verses 1-10)
Pay attention to the contrast between the 'city of salvation' (v.1-2) and the 'dust' (v.19-20)
The phrase 'perfect peace' (v.3) is emphasized as a result of trust

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Judah) is singing a song of trust, WHAT (the LORD as their salvation and rock), WHERE (the land of Judah), and WHY (because they trust in the LORD for perfect peace and resurrection hope).
tips: Include the call to open the gates for the righteous nation (v.1-2)
Note the promise of perfect peace for the trusting (v.3)
Mention the resurrection hope and the hiding of the people until judgment passes (v.19-24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the 'perfect peace' (v.3), the 'everlasting rock' (v.6), or the 'resurrection hope' (v.19-20)?
tips: The phrase 'perfect peace' (v.3) is a promise of stability in the midst of chaos
The image of the LORD as an 'everlasting rock' (v.6) provides a foundation that won't be shaken
The promise that 'the dead shall live' (v.19) brings hope beyond death

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is calling Judah to trust in the LORD as their salvation and rock, especially in the midst of impending judgment
This passage reassures Judah that the LORD is their eternal protector and the one who will ultimately triumph over their enemies
The theme of resurrection hope is a promise of future restoration for Judah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'perfect peace' in the midst of judgment? The resurrection in the context of the present? The 'dust' as a place of hiding?
tips: Perfect peace (v.3) is a state of mind that comes from absolute trust in the LORD, not the absence of trouble
The resurrection hope (v.19) is a future promise that the dead will be raised, which is a key Christian doctrine but also a hope for Judah's restoration
The phrase 'the foot tramples it, the feet of the poor' (v.19) describes how the LORD humbles the powerful and lifts up the poor, which may be hard to visualize in a current context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'perfect peace' from this passage. What situation requires you to trust in the LORD for peace this week?
tips: Consider a stressor in your life and how you can focus on the LORD for peace (v.3)
Pray for the strength to trust in the LORD even when circumstances are chaotic
Practice 'hiding' in the LORD (v.19) by spending time in quiet reflection

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of 'perfect peace' and 'the LORD as an everlasting rock'.
tips: Thank God for the promise of perfect peace that comes from trust in Him
Ask for the courage to hide in the LORD when life is difficult (v.19)
Pray for the resurrection hope that the LORD will restore and bring peace to your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 27:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'Leviathan the fleeing serpent' (v.1), 'I have no wrath' (v.5), and 'the great trumpet' (v.14).
tips: Note the repetition of 'Leviathan' as two distinct serpents in verse 1
Pay attention to the phrase 'I have no wrath' (v.5) which contrasts with God's judgment on Leviathan
Notice the contrast between the sea (where Leviathan is slain) and the vineyard (on dry land) in the passage

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is doing what, WHERE it happens, and WHY God is acting in this passage.
tips: God slays Leviathan (Satan) in the sea (v.1)
God waters and protects the vineyard (the church) every moment (v.3)
The great trumpet will gather the lost to worship in Jerusalem (v.14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's slaying of Leviathan (v.1), the vineyard's care (v.3), or the great trumpet (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'I have no wrath' (v.5) shows God's patience and love for His vineyard
Jacob taking root and Israel blossoming (v.6) is a powerful promise of restoration for the future
The great trumpet (v.14) as a sign of God's gathering of the lost to worship in Jerusalem is a hopeful image of the end times

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah reassures Judah that God will deliver them from the enemy (Satan) and restore their relationship with Him
The vineyard represents Israel (the church) that God will tend and protect from destruction
This passage points to the future restoration of the church and the gathering of all people to worship God in Jerusalem

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of Leviathan, the phrase 'I have no wrath', and the meaning of the great trumpet.
tips: Leviathan in ancient Near Eastern context was a sea monster symbolizing chaos and evil, but here it represents Satan (the serpent) and the enemy of God's people
The phrase 'I have no wrath' (v.5) might seem contradictory to God's judgment on Leviathan (v.1), but it shows God's patience with His vineyard (the church)
The 'great trumpet' (v.14) is a sign of God's judgment and gathering, but in Isaiah's time, trumpets were used for war and warnings; here it points to the gathering of the lost for worship

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does God's care for His vineyard (the church) apply to your life this week? Consider an area where you feel like the church is being threatened.
tips: Think about a current stressor in your life or community that might be like the enemy (Leviathan) threatening the vineyard
Pray for God to water and protect your spiritual life (the vineyard) as He does for His church
Ask for courage to be part of the 'blossoming' of the church in your community this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance of His church from the enemy and ask for His protection and restoration.
tips: Thank God that He slays the serpent (Satan) and protects His vineyard (the church)
Pray for the church to take root and blossom in your life and community
Ask God to blow the great trumpet in your life, gathering you to worship Him in Jerusalem (the New Jerusalem)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 28:1-13 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the current state of Ephraim and the future promise of the LORD.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'woe' and the description of Ephraim as 'drunkards'
Pay attention to the phrase 'reel with wine and stagger with strong drink' (v. 11)
Listen for the shift in tone from judgment to hope in the stone of foundation (v. 11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is being warned, what they are doing that is wrong, where this is happening, and why Isaiah is warning them.
tips: Include Ephraim as the proud crown of the drunkards
Note that the priest and prophet are also drunk (v. 11)
Highlight the promise of the LORD laying a stone that is a foundation for the remnant

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of the passage stands out the most? Consider: the description of Ephraim's condition (v. 1), the promise of the stone (v. 11), or the teaching method (v. 10)?
tips: The phrase 'a tested stone, a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation' (v. 11) is powerful because it shows God's reliability and the promise of eternal security
The contrast in v. 10: 'To whom will He teach knowledge? To those just weaned?' shows the gradual nature of God's teaching, which resonates with modern times when people feel rushed
The image of the priest and prophet 'reeling' (v. 11) is a strong metaphor for spiritual blindness and the consequences of sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about their current state and God's future promise?
tips: The warning is that Ephraim's pride and drunkenness (sin) will lead to destruction, but God will provide a foundation (the cornerstone) for those who remain faithful
This passage points to the future of the remnant who will be used by God for justice and strength
The cornerstone is a type of Christ, who is the foundation of the church (1 Peter 2:6)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging? The phrase 'covenant with death'? The meaning of 'precious cornerstone'? The teaching method 'precept upon precept'?
tips: 'Covenant with death' (v. 12) means that the people have chosen a path that leads to death (sin) rather than life with God
The 'precious cornerstone' (v. 11) is a stone that is both tested (refined) and precious, symbolizing Christ as the one who is the foundation of the new covenant
'Precept upon precept, line upon line' (v. 10) means that God teaches in a gradual, step-by-step manner, not in a single, overwhelming way

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of the cornerstone (v. 11) to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel unstable and build your life on the foundation of God's word (the cornerstone)
Practice patience in teaching others, as God teaches step by step (precept upon precept)
Avoid the 'drunkenness' of sin by being sober and alert in your faith

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the remnant of God's people to be a community of justice and strength, and for you to avoid the drunkenness of sin.
tips: Thank God for the promise of the cornerstone (Christ) that we can stand on
Ask for the strength to be sober and not to 'reel with wine'
Pray for the church to be a place of justice and strength, as described in v. 13

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 29:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'Ariel' and the phrase 'the city where David encamped' in verse 1.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Ariel' (v.1) as a city name and symbol of God's presence
The phrase 'the vision of all this has become like the words of a sealed book' (v.12) conveys a sense of mystery and divine secrecy
The emotional tone shifts from judgment (v.5-6) to hope (v.14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is judging, WHAT happens to Ariel, WHERE it occurs, and WHY in Isaiah 29:1-14.
tips: Include the city Ariel (where David encamped) as the target of judgment
Note that the judgment comes because the people honor God with their lips but their hearts are far from Him (v.13)
Mention the coming judgment: the LORD will visit with thunder, earthquake, and fire (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the city of Ariel (v.1), the sealed book (v.12), or the promise of God's provision (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'the city where David encamped' (v.1) connects Ariel to God's past covenant with David
The sealed book (v.12) symbolizes how the people's understanding is blocked, but God will unseal it for those who are humble (v.14)
The promise in v.14: 'I will again do wonderful things' points to God's active faithfulness despite current failure

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage of Isaiah 29:1-14?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that their religious rituals without heartfelt faith will lead to judgment
The passage also promises that God will restore the city and the people who truly seek Him
This is a call to move from external religious behavior to internal spiritual transformation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of Isaiah 29:1-14 are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The sealed book (v.12) refers to the prophetic message being inaccessible without divine intervention
The phrase 'the multitude of nations that fight against Ariel shall be like a dream' (v.6) suggests that the enemies' actions will be fleeting and meaningless
The concept of 'lip service' (v.13) is a common modern issue but in ancient Judah, it meant religious rituals without true devotion

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'lip service without heart' (Isaiah 29:13) to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be doing religious activities without genuine commitment
Pray for humility and a heart that truly seeks God, as Isaiah promises for those who are humble
Spend time in quiet reflection to ensure your worship is from the heart

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about Isaiah 29:1-14: asking for God to reveal your heart and to remove the lip service in your life.
tips: Thank God for His promise to do wonderful things for those who seek Him (v.14)
Ask for the strength to move from external religious behavior to heartfelt worship
Pray for the ability to see the sealed book (v.12) as an opportunity for God to open understanding

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 30:1-23 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the rebels' actions and God's promises of grace.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'woe' in the opening verses (v.1)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the rebels' rebellion (v.3: 'lying children')
Highlight the phrase 'bread of adversity' (v.19) as a key metaphor for trials

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being rebuked, WHAT they are doing, WHERE they are going, WHY they are rebellious, and HOW God responds.
tips: The rebellious children of Judah (v.1)
Their plan to seek refuge in Egypt without God's direction (v.1)
God's promise of grace and restoration for those who return to Him (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the rebels' refusal to listen (v.3), the promise of rest and salvation (v.15), or God's waiting grace (v.18)?
tips: The promise 'in returning and rest you shall be saved' (v.15) is a powerful call to restoration
God's patience: 'the LORD waits to be gracious' (v.18) shows His compassion
The final line: 'Though the Lord give you the bread of adversity, your Teacher will not hide Himself anymore' (v.19) emphasizes God's constant presence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah against their idolatrous alliance with Egypt and their rejection of God's guidance
He emphasizes that true salvation comes through God's grace and trust, not human alliances
The theological significance: God's promise to be gracious to those who return to Him (v.18) and the contrast with Egypt's false security

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The rebels' rebellion against God's direction (v.1), the concept of 'bread of adversity' (v.19), or the role of Egypt in Judah's rebellion?
tips: 'Bread of adversity' (v.19) refers to trials God may allow, but He does not abandon His presence
In ancient Near Eastern context, Egypt was a powerful ally for Judah, but the passage condemns this reliance
'Adding sin to sin' (v.1) means the rebels are increasing their sin through their choices

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of trust in God's provision (not in human alliances). What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week?
tips: Consider an area where you might be seeking help from others (like friends or institutions) instead of God
How can you practice 'returning and rest' (v.15) in your current situation?
When you feel like you are in adversity, remember that God remains with you (v.19)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His patience and ask for the courage to return to Him.
tips: Thank God for His patience with us despite our rebellion
Pray for the strength to choose God's guidance over worldly alliances
Ask God to strengthen your trust in His provision when you are in adversity

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 31:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between human reliance and God's sovereignty.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'do not look to the Holy One of Israel' (v. 1)
Pay attention to the contrast in verses 4-5: 'Egypt is man, and not God, and their horses are flesh, and not spirit'
Notice the emotional tone of warning and hope in verses 5-6

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is warned, WHAT they are doing, WHERE they are turning, and WHY God is acting.
tips: Include the people of Judah who are relying on Egypt for military help
Note the specific contrast: Egypt (man) vs. the Holy One of Israel (God)
Describe God's response: coming down to fight on Mount Zion and protecting Jerusalem

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of Egypt as 'man and not God' (v. 4), the lion imagery (v. 5), or the birds hovering (v. 5).
tips: The phrase 'Egypt is man, and not God' is a powerful contrast that highlights the futility of human power
The image of the LORD coming down like a lion to fight on Mount Zion shows God's active, protective nature
The birds hovering as a sign of protection is a gentle, watchful image that contrasts with the violence of the lion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah's purpose was to warn Judah against false security and idolatry by turning to Egypt
He emphasizes that God is the true protector and that the people must turn to Him
This passage also points to God's sovereignty and His promise to deliver Jerusalem

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The comparison of Egypt to man and horses to flesh, the metaphor of the lion and birds, or the call to turn from Egypt.
tips: The phrase 'Egypt is man, and not God' uses a metaphor to show that Egypt is temporary and mortal, unlike God who is eternal
The 'lion' and 'birds hovering' are vivid images that might be hard to relate to modern contexts, but they show God's active protection
The command to 'turn to Him from whom people have deeply revolted' (v. 1) is a call to repentance that requires humility

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage this week? Identify one area where you're relying on human strength (like Egypt) and turn to God for provision.
tips: Consider a situation where you're trusting in your own abilities or worldly resources instead of God
Practice turning to God by praying for His wisdom and protection in that area
Surrender a specific worry to God, like the fear of being overwhelmed by life's challenges

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His protection and ask for courage to turn away from false idols.
tips: Thank God for being the true protector of Jerusalem (and your life)
Pray for the strength to reject false security (like Egypt) and trust in God
Ask God to help you see the futility of human power and the reality of His provision

chapters.chapterTitle: A King Will Reign in Righteousness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 32:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the metaphors of shelter and transformation.
tips: Notice the repeated metaphors: 'hiding place from the wind', 'shelter from the storm', 'streams of water in a dry place', 'shade of a great rock'
Pay attention to the contrast between current complacency and promised restoration
The phrase 'until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high' (v.15) is a key phrase in the context

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the king and princes), WHAT (will reign in righteousness and rule in justice), WHERE (the land of Judah), and WHY (to bring restoration and justice to the land).
tips: Include the king's reign in righteousness and princes ruling in justice
Note the transformation: wilderness becomes a fruitful field
The coming of the Spirit that transforms the land

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the king's reign in righteousness (v.1), the transformation of the wilderness (v.13-14), or the call to the women (v.6).
tips: The metaphor of the 'shelter from the storm' (v.2) is a powerful image of safety in chaos
The contrast in v.13: 'until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high, and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field' shows dramatic transformation
The call to the women: 'Rise up, you women who are at ease; hear my voice' (v.6) is a direct address to complacent people, urging them to listen

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is warning Judah of their current spiritual and social decay (complacency, failing harvest) but promising future restoration through God's righteous king and Spirit's outpouring
The restoration is not just physical but spiritual: the land becomes fruitful because of God's presence and the Spirit's work

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The promise of a king reigning in righteousness (v.1), the transformation of the wilderness (v.13-14), and the call to the women (v.6).
tips: The term 'king' in Isaiah 32:1 refers to God as the ultimate king (Christ) who will reign in righteousness, not a human king
The phrase 'wilderness becomes a fruitful field' (v.14) is a common metaphor for God's restoration of barren lands (e.g., post-exilic Israel)
The call to 'women who are at ease' (v.6) addresses those who are complacent in their current state, warning that comfort is temporary

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of the king reigning in righteousness (v.1) and the transformation of the land (v.13-14). What specific action can you take this week to be a 'shelter from the storm' for others?
tips: Pray for the Spirit to transform your life and community, turning barren places into fruitful fields
Share your experiences of being a shelter (like the shade of a rock) for someone in distress
Spend time in the Word to understand how the righteous king (Christ) rules in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the righteous king who will rule over a restored land and ask for the Spirit to pour out on your life.
tips: Thank God that He is the righteous king who will rule over a restored land

questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 39:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Hezekiah and Isaiah in verses 3-5.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I have seen' in Hezekiah's response (v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'all that is in my house' (v.2) which shows Hezekiah's pride
Note the emotional shift in Isaiah's prophecy: from the display of treasures to the coming exile (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Hezekiah, Merodach-baladan, envoys), WHAT (the envoys from Babylon sent letters and presents to Hezekiah after he recovered from illness), WHERE (in Jerusalem), and WHY (to assess the health and wealth of Hezekiah's kingdom).
tips: Include that Hezekiah showed his treasures to the envoys (v.2)
Note that Isaiah was called to ask the envoys about their purpose and what they had seen (v.4)
Hezekiah's response: 'They came from Babylon' and 'They have seen all that is in my house' (v.3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hezekiah's pride in displaying his treasures (v.2), Isaiah's prophecy of exile (v.7), or Hezekiah's declaration of peace (v.8)?
tips: Hezekiah's statement: 'They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them' shows his pride and lack of awareness of God's sovereignty
The prophecy: 'Days are coming when all that is in your house shall be carried to Babylon. Nothing shall be left' (v.7) is a stark warning of future judgment
Hezekiah's response: 'The word of the LORD is good—for there shall be peace in my days' (v.8) is a hopeful declaration that contrasts with the coming exile

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage? How does this prophecy relate to the future of Judah?
tips: Isaiah warns that Judah's wealth and power are temporary and will be taken by Babylon
The prophecy foreshadows the Babylonian exile that would happen 70 years later
Hezekiah's declaration of peace (v.8) is a temporary peace that comes from God's word, but the exile is the ultimate consequence of pride and self-reliance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The timing of the exile, the meaning of 'all that is in your house', or the contrast between Hezekiah's peace and the coming exile?
tips: The phrase 'all that is in your house' (v.2) refers to both physical treasures and the spiritual wealth of the kingdom, not just material possessions
In the context of the time, Babylon was a powerful empire that had not yet attacked Judah, so the prophecy of exile was a future event that Isaiah was foretelling
The term 'treasures' in ancient Near Eastern context included not only gold and silver but also military equipment and religious artifacts

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of humility and the danger of pride in displaying your treasures (both material and spiritual) this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are proud of your possessions or achievements and how it might lead to spiritual blindness
Practice humility by sharing your resources with others, especially those who are in need
Reflect on what you would do if you knew that your treasures would one day be taken away

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for His warning and for the hope that comes from His word (v.8)
Pray for humility in your own life and for the courage to surrender your treasures to God
Ask for protection from the pride that causes us to display our wealth without considering the consequences

questions.title: Best Bit

tips: The phrase 'Fear not, I am with you' is a direct comfort to Israel in their distress
The description of the one from the east (the Messiah) who brings victory is a powerful hope
The term 'Redeemer' (v.10) emphasizes God's active role in saving Israel from their enemies

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: To reassure Judah that God is their eternal protector and helper, especially during their exile

This passage foreshadows Christ as the one from the east who will be the Redeemer

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: 'One from the east' refers to the coming of the Messiah (Christ) who will be victorious over nations
'Worm' (v.13) is a term of endearment for Jacob, meaning 'the small one' but here it's used to show God's intimate relationship
God holding your hand (v.10) is a metaphor for divine support in times of fear

questions.title: Application

tips: When you feel overwhelmed, remember that God is with you and will strengthen you
