tips: Notice the repetition of 'I am the LORD' (v. 5, 20)
Pay attention to the phrase 'your name' appearing three times (v. 4, 7, 20)
The emotional tone shifts from divine authority to intimate calling (v. 7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (grasps Cyrus, calls him by name) WHERE (in the context of Judah's exile) and WHY (to set free the exiles and build the temple).
tips: Include: God's anointing of Cyrus to subdue nations
Note: Cyrus is called 'the anointed' (v. 1)
Describe the purpose: building the temple and freeing the exiles

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's declaration of being the only God (v. 5-6), Cyrus's role in building the temple (v. 1-2), or the universal call (v. 20-25).
tips: The phrase 'I form light and create darkness' (v. 6) shows God's creative power and control over all things
Cyrus being 'the anointed' (v. 1) and God's promise to him (v. 4) highlights divine sovereignty
The universal declaration: 'To Me every knee shall bow' (v. 23) is a powerful promise of global submission

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about Cyrus?
tips: Isaiah was reassuring Judah that God would use Cyrus (a Gentile) to bring about the restoration of Jerusalem and the temple
The main point is that God is sovereign over all nations and will use Cyrus to fulfill His purpose for Israel
This passage also foreshadows Christ as the ultimate anointed one who will set captives free (Phil 2:10-11)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The anointing of Cyrus, the concept of 'treasures of darkness', and the universal call to bow?
tips: Cyrus was a Persian king who was not a chosen one in the Jewish sense; Isaiah uses him as a tool of God's will
'Treasures of darkness' (v. 4) likely refers to the wealth of nations Cyrus would plunder, but God reveals His power through these treasures
The universal call (v. 23) is a promise that all nations will bow to God, which is fulfilled in Christ's reign

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply God's promise of being the anointed one in your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel like you are not the chosen one, but God has a purpose for you
Think about how God might use you to set others free (like Cyrus did)
Pray for courage to be the 'anointed' in your community, even when it's costly

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for the courage to be used by Him in your life.
tips: Thank God for being the only God (v. 5)
Pray for the strength to trust God's anointing in your life
Ask for the boldness to set others free (like Cyrus did)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 46:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Babylon's idols and God's promise.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I am He' (v.4) and 'I will carry' (v.4, 10)
Pay attention to the contrast: Babylon's idols 'cannot move' (v.5) vs. God 'carries' (v.4, 10)
The emotional tone shifts from the helplessness of idols to God's enduring presence

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (carries His people) WHERE (from womb to old age) and WHY (to show He is the only God who can save).
tips: Include the image of Babylon's idols being burdens that cannot save (v.1-5)
Note that God promises to carry His people from birth to old age (v.4, 10)
Highlight the contrast: idols are carried by people (v.1) but God carries the people (v.4, 10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the burden of Babylon's gods (v.1-5), God's promise to carry (v.4, 10), or the rhetorical question 'To whom will you liken Me?' (v.5)?
tips: The phrase 'I am He' (v.4) is powerful because it declares God's unchanging identity
The image of idols 'cannot move from its place' (v.5) is a stark contrast to God's active care
The rhetorical question 'To whom will you liken Me?' (v.5) challenges the people to consider the true God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is warning Judah against idolatry by showing the futility of Babylon's gods and the sufficiency of God's promise
He emphasizes God's personal covenant care (from womb to old age) to counter the idolatrous practices of the time
This passage serves as a theological foundation for the New Testament concept of Christ bearing believers

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The burden of Babylon's gods? Why God 'carries' His people? The meaning of 'I am He'?
tips: Babylon's gods were a common practice in the Assyrian context, but Isaiah shows they are powerless (v.5) to provide salvation
The phrase 'I am He' (v.4) is a declaration of God's eternal identity, not a temporal promise
The term 'burden' (Hebrew: 'kavod') refers to the weight of sin and the consequences of idolatry, but God carries His people from that burden

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: God carries His people from spiritual birth to eternal glory. What area of your life needs to be carried by God this week?
tips: Identify one burden you are carrying (e.g., anxiety, sin, fear) and ask God to take it
Practice trusting God's promise to carry you, even when you feel heavy
Like the people of Judah, surrender your burdens to God and let Him be your strength

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He carries us from womb to old age. Ask for courage to release burdens to Him.
tips: Thank God for being the only God who carries us (v.4, 10)
Pray for the strength to let go of idols and trust in God's provision
Ask God to help you experience His carrying in your current struggles

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 47:1-14 aloud, focusing on the contrast between Babylon's pride and God's sovereignty.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'sit' (v.1, v.7) and 'you shall no more be called' (v.1, v.8) to show Babylon's loss of status
Pay attention to the phrase 'I am, and there is no one besides me' (v.12) which emphasizes God's absolute authority
The phrase 'loss of children and widowhood' (v.13) is a stark warning of total destruction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is being judged, what God is doing, where this judgment occurs, and why Babylon is being destroyed.
tips: Babylon (the Chaldeans) is being judged by God for their pride and lack of mercy
God is taking vengeance on Babylon for the suffering of Judah
This occurs in the context of God's wrath against the nations that oppressed Judah

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stands out most? Consider: the declaration of God's absolute sovereignty (v.12), the imagery of Babylon's humiliation (v.3-4), or the suddenness of destruction (v.13-14)?
tips: The phrase 'I am, and there is no one besides me' (v.12) is a powerful declaration of God's oneness and absolute authority
The image of Babylon 'taking the millstones and grinding flour' (v.3) shows her loss of power and purpose
The suddenness of 'loss of children and widowhood' (v.13) highlights the total devastation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about the fate of Babylon and God's role as the Redeemer?
tips: Isaiah warns Judah that Babylon's pride will lead to her downfall, but God is the ultimate Redeemer (v.11) who will judge all worldly powers
This passage foreshadows Christ as the true 'Redeemer' who will judge the nations and restore Israel
The 'LORD of hosts' (v.11) is a title for Christ who will ultimately triumph over all enemies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The term 'virgin daughter of Babylon', the phrase 'I shall be mistress forever', and the concept of God's vengeance?
tips: In Isaiah, 'virgin' refers to a city that has not yet been conquered (like a virgin city), but here it's used to show Babylon's innocence in her own pride
Babylon's claim of eternal power (v.12) is a boast that God will shatter
The phrase 'I will take vengeance and spare no one' (v.8) indicates complete destruction without mercy, which is a warning against pride

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'pride leading to destruction' in your life this week?
tips: Reflect on a situation where you have been overly proud or self-reliant, like Babylon claiming eternal power
Pray for humility and a willingness to surrender to God's sovereignty
Spend time in prayer this week asking God to help you avoid the pride that leads to destruction

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the warning against pride and the hope in God's redemption.
tips: Thank God that He is the ultimate Redeemer and that Babylon's fall is a sign of His judgment on pride
Ask for the courage to humble yourself and trust God's provision in difficult circumstances
Pray for a heart that recognizes God's sovereignty and rejects the false claim of eternal power

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 48:1-20 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'I' (the LORD) as speaker and the emotional shift from warning to hope.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I have refined you, but not as silver' (v.10) — a unique image of refining
Pay attention to Judah's 'obstinate' nature (v.4) and the 'iron sinew' and 'bronze forehead' descriptions
Observe the emotional tone shift from stern warning to hopeful promise of redemption (v.18-19)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the LORD) is doing WHAT (refining and redeeming) to WHOM (Judah) in WHERE (the furnace of affliction) and WHY (due to Judah's stubbornness).
tips: Include the LORD's refining process as a test of faith (v.10-11)
Note Judah's stubbornness and failure to heed the LORD's commandments (v.4, 18)
Highlight the outcome: redemption from Babylon and peace for the obedient (v.18-19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the refining process (v.10-11), the call to go out from Babylon (v.18), or the promise of peace (v.19)?
tips: The phrase 'I have refined you, but not as silver' (v.10) — shows the LORD's care in the refining process
The contrast between 'no peace for the wicked' (v.19) and peace like a river for the redeemed (v.18) — a powerful promise
The declaration 'Go out from Babylon!' (v.18) — a direct call to leave captivity and trust in the LORD

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah calls Judah to repent and trust in the LORD's refining process for redemption and peace
The theological significance: The LORD's refining produces genuine faith and obedience, not just temporary relief
This passage foreshadows Christ's refining in the furnace (the cross) and His role as the peace that surpasses understanding

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The refining process, the call to leave Babylon, or the promise of peace?
tips: The phrase 'I have refined you, but not as silver' (v.10) — in contrast to silver which is refined without damage, Judah is refined in a way that causes harm
The term 'Babylon' here refers to exile or any oppressive situation (not just the city of Babylon)
The statement 'no peace for the wicked' (v.19) — emphasizes the wicked will not experience the peace the redeemed do

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of being refined in affliction to your life this week?
tips: Identify a trial (furnace of affliction) and ask how the LORD is refining you (v.10)
Pray for courage to leave the 'Babylon' of your life and trust in the LORD's redemption (v.18)
Commit to obey the LORD's commandments to experience peace like a river (v.19)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of being refined by the LORD and the promise of peace.
tips: Thank the LORD for refining you and the promise of peace through obedience
Ask for strength to endure trials without becoming stubborn (like Judah's 'iron sinew')
Pray for grace to leave the 'Babylon' of your life and experience the LORD's peace

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Isaiah 49 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 50:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the servant's suffering and God's power.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I' (the servant) and 'the LORD' (God) to see the relationship
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the servant's submission (e.g., 'I hid not My face from disgrace')
The phrase 'by My rebuke I dry up the sea' shows God's power

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the servant) is being tested, WHAT (the servant's obedience to God), WHERE (in the context of Judah), and WHY (to show God's redemption and the servant's faithfulness).
tips: The servant is the one who is God's chosen one (the Messiah)
The servant is struck and has his beard pulled but remains obedient
The servant is not disgraced because God helps him

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the servant's response to being struck (v. 4), the phrase 'I hid not My face from disgrace' (v. 5), or the declaration of God's help (v. 9)?
tips: The servant's willingness to take the punishment without turning back (v. 4) shows deep obedience
The phrase 'I hid not My face from disgrace' (v. 5) shows humility and acceptance of suffering
The declaration 'the Lord GOD helps Me' (v. 9) is a powerful statement of trust

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about God's role in the servant's obedience and redemption?
tips: Isaiah is showing that God will provide a servant who is obedient even when suffering
This passage points to the future Messiah who would be the obedient servant (Christ)
The theme of redemption through obedience is central

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The servant's willingness to be struck, the phrase 'the tongue of those who are taught', the concept of God 'drying up the sea'?
tips: The phrase 'the tongue of those who are taught' (v. 4) refers to the servant having the ability to speak with wisdom from God
The phrase 'drying up the sea' (v. 2) is a metaphor for God's power to accomplish what seems impossible
The servant's obedience to God even when being struck is a concept that requires understanding of the servant's identity (the Messiah)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the servant's obedience to your life this week? Specifically, when faced with being 'struck' by life's challenges, what does the passage teach you to do?
tips: When you face criticism or hardship, remember the servant's response: 'I hid not My face from disgrace'
Surrender your pride and accept the 'striking' as part of God's discipline
Pray for the strength to be 'the tongue of those who are taught' in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the servant who obeys even when suffering. Ask for the courage to face life's challenges without turning back.
tips: Thank God that He provides the strength to endure suffering like the servant
Pray for the grace to not be disgraced by life's trials
Ask God to help you hide your face from disgrace (i.e., maintain dignity) when faced with hardship

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 51:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the repeated call to 'awake' and the contrast between the wilderness and Eden.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'awake' in verses 1 and 3
Pay attention to the phrase 'rock from which you were hewn' in verse 2
The contrast between 'wilderness' and 'Eden' in verses 3-4

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is called, WHAT God promises, WHERE this promise is for, and WHY it matters to Judah.
tips: Include the call to awaken the people of Judah
Note the comparison of Zion to Eden
Mention the eternal nature of God's salvation

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to awaken (v1), the rock metaphor (v2), or the wilderness becoming Eden (v3)?
tips: The phrase 'wilderness like Eden' shows God's transformative power
The promise that salvation is forever (v4) is a strong contrast to the temporary nature of the heavens and earth (v4)
The image of the arm of the LORD awakening is powerful as a sign of God's active intervention

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is addressing the exiled people of Judah, promising restoration and a new covenant
He emphasizes that God's salvation is eternal and will bring renewal to a broken land
This passage is a call to hope and trust in God's promises despite current desolation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'arm of the LORD' (v1), the wilderness becoming Eden (v3), or the eternal salvation (v4)?
tips: 'Arm of the LORD' refers to God's active power, not a physical arm
The wilderness becoming Eden is a metaphor for God's restoration of the land and people
The phrase 'salvation forever' contrasts with the temporary nature of the heavens and earth (v4)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's eternal salvation to your life this week?
tips: Think about a situation where you feel lost or in a wilderness
Pray for God to transform your current circumstances into a place of Eden
Commit to trusting God's eternal plan even when things seem temporary

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His eternal salvation and ask for the courage to awaken in your life.
tips: Thank God for turning your wilderness into Eden
Ask for the strength to be the 'arm of the LORD' in your community
Pray for the people of Judah to return with singing

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 52:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the call to Zion in verses 1-2 and the beautiful feet in verse 7.
tips: Note the repetition of 'awake' in verse 1
Pay attention to the phrase 'the feet of him who brings good news' in verse 7
Notice the shift from judgment to redemption in verses 3-5

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Zion, Jerusalem, the LORD) is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it is happening.
tips: Include the call to wake up and put on beautiful garments
Note the redemption without cost and the lifting of the bonds
Mention the watchmen singing and the return of the LORD

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the beautiful feet (v.7), the phrase 'Your God reigns' (v.7), or the watchmen singing (v.12).
tips: The beautiful feet symbolize the coming of the gospel
The phrase 'Your God reigns' is a declaration of God's authority and presence
The watchmen singing together shows the joy of the redeemed community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is calling Judah to wake up and recognize God's redemption
The passage emphasizes that God's deliverance is without cost and the gospel is coming
This passage foreshadows the coming of the Messiah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'the uncircumcised and the unclean' (v.1), the Servant being 'marred beyond human semblance' (v.13), and 'the LORD has bared His holy arm' (v.10).
tips: 'Uncircumcised' here refers to those not part of the covenant (the unclean might mean sinners)
The Servant's marred appearance points to the crucifixion of Christ
Baring the holy arm means God's power is visible to all nations

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a 'beautiful foot' in your community this week, bringing the good news of God's redemption?
tips: Share the gospel with someone this week
Be a witness of God's love in your actions
Pray for the broken to be healed as the LORD redeems

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's redemption to come to your life and community, and for you to be a witness of His beauty.
tips: Thank God for the coming of His salvation
Ask for courage to share the gospel
Pray for the unclean to be cleansed by His grace

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 53:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the description of the suffering servant in verses 3-7.
tips: Notice the phrase 'He was despised and rejected by men' (v.3) repeated in the context of the servant's suffering
Pay attention to the lamb imagery in verse 7: 'He was led like a lamb to slaughter'
Notice the silence of the servant: 'He opened not His mouth' (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the suffering servant) is doing WHAT (bearing our griefs and carrying our sorrows), WHERE (in the land of the living, but then taken away), and WHY (to atone for the sins of Judah).
tips: Include the servant's despising by men (v.3)
Note the piercing and crushing for transgressions (v.5)
Describe the burial with the wicked (v.9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the servant being a lamb (v.7), the piercing for transgressions (v.5), or the silence of the servant (v.7).
tips: The lamb imagery (v.7) is powerful because it connects the servant to the sacrificial system of the Old Testament
The phrase 'He was pierced for our transgressions' (v.5) shows the direct link between the servant's suffering and the sins of the people
The silence of the servant (v.7) emphasizes his humility and the lack of complaint in bearing the burden

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about the suffering servant?
tips: Isaiah was addressing Judah and showing that the suffering servant would come to atone for their sins and bring them peace
This passage was a response to the unfaithfulness of Judah and their need for a savior
The theological significance is that the servant's suffering is the means of salvation for the people of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The servant being a lamb to slaughter, the piercing for transgressions, and the burial with the wicked.
tips: 'Lamb to slaughter' (v.7) is a metaphor for the servant's death as a sacrifice, not literal slaughter
'Pierced for transgressions' (v.5) means the servant bore the punishment for the sins of others in the sense of the atonement
Burial with the wicked (v.9) shows the servant died as a criminal, but in reality he was the righteous one who was raised

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage describes the suffering servant as despised and rejected. What can you do this week to be like the servant who is despised for the sake of others?
tips: Consider an area where you feel rejected by others and how you can be humble in that situation
Practice being a 'lamb' by carrying burdens without complaint (like the servant who was silent)
How can you be willing to suffer for others without seeking recognition?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the suffering servant who was despised and rejected for our sake. Ask for strength to be like Him in bearing burdens.
tips: Thank God for sending a servant who was despised and rejected for our sins
Pray for courage to be humble and silent in the face of suffering
Ask God to help you to be a servant who bears the burdens of others without complaint

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 54:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of God's promise and the repetition of 'covenant' and 'peace'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'barren one' (v.1) which contrasts with the abundance of God's promises
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'I will not be angry' (v.8) and 'My steadfast love shall not depart' (v.10)
The phrase 'everlasting covenant of peace' (v.10) is the key promise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is addressing, WHAT He promises, WHERE this promise is being made, and WHY He is making it.
tips: The 'barren one' (Judah) is the one God is addressing
God promises to restore and bless them despite their past desolation
This happens in the context of the exile and the future restoration of the people

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's declaration of restoration (v.6), the comparison to Noah (v.8), or the covenant of peace (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'For a brief moment I deserted you, but with great compassion I will gather you' (v.6) shows God's timely intervention
The comparison to the days of Noah (v.8) emphasizes God's unchanging promise of restoration
The declaration of the 'everlasting covenant of peace' (v.10) is the central promise of this chapter

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: The main point is that God, as the husband of the church, will restore Judah and establish an everlasting covenant of peace despite their past desolation
This passage addresses the fear of Judah's future and reassures them of God's enduring love
The covenant of peace is contrasted with the temporary nature of the old covenant (the Mosaic covenant) and points to the new covenant in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'barren one', the concept of God's 'brief anger', and the meaning of 'covenant of peace'?
tips: The term 'barren one' (v.1) refers to the desolate state of Jerusalem after the exile, but also to the church as a new community
'Brief anger' (v.6) is a temporary state of God's discipline, not a permanent abandonment
The 'covenant of peace' (v.10) is a promise that God's love and commitment will never be broken, unlike the temporary covenants of the old law

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply God's promise of the everlasting covenant of peace in your life this week?
tips: When you feel abandoned or desolate, remember God's promise to gather you
Surrender your fears of being 'barren' to God's covenant of peace
Pray for God's steadfast love to guide you through current trials

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His everlasting covenant of peace and ask for His help in applying it to your life.
tips: Thank God for being your husband and Redeemer
Ask for courage to trust in His promise of restoration
Pray for the church to experience the 'everlasting covenant of peace' in the midst of trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 55:1-11 aloud, focusing on the phrases: 'Come, everyone who thirsts', 'buy and eat', and 'without money and without price'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'come' (v.1, v.2, v.5)
Pay attention to the contrast between human effort and God's free provision (v.1-2)
The emotional tone shifts from invitation to urgency in verses 6-8

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Judah) is called, WHAT (to come to the waters of the Lord's provision) they are to do, WHERE (in the spiritual realm) this happens, and WHY (because they are thirsty and in need of God's covenant love).
tips: The invitation to come without money or price (v.1-2) shows God's generosity
The call to seek the Lord while He is near (v.6) emphasizes urgency
The promise of an everlasting covenant with David (v.3) is a key promise for the nation

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the invitation to come without cost (v.1-2), the call to seek the LORD while He may be found (v.6), or the promise of an everlasting covenant (v.3).
tips: The phrase 'Seek the LORD while He may be found' (v.6) is urgent and practical for anyone in spiritual drought
The promise of an everlasting covenant (v.3) provides hope for the future of the nation
The contrast in verse 8-9: 'My thoughts are not your thoughts' shows God's sovereignty and the need for humility

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is calling Judah to stop relying on their own resources and turn to God's free provision
The everlasting covenant with David (the king) is a promise that God will remain faithful despite their unfaithfulness
This passage addresses the spiritual thirst of Judah who have turned away from the Lord

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'come without money', the concept of an everlasting covenant, or the idea that God's thoughts are not human thoughts?
tips: 'Without money and without price' (v.1) might seem counterintuitive in a culture that values trade and barter
The 'everlasting covenant' with David (v.3) is a promise that spans generations and is not temporary
The phrase 'My thoughts are not your thoughts' (v.8) emphasizes that God's perspective is different from ours and requires humility

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, when you feel like you are spiritually thirsty, apply the call to 'seek the LORD while He may be found' (v.6).
tips: Identify one area where you need God's provision instead of your own efforts
Take a moment to pray for the Lord's presence when you feel distant from Him
Ask God to help you see the urgency of seeking Him now

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His free provision of the Lord's presence. Ask for courage to seek Him while He is near, and for the assurance of His everlasting covenant.
tips: Thank God for the promise of an everlasting covenant with David
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you understand God's perspective
Ask God to help you seek Him when you are in spiritual drought

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 56:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the foreigner and eunuch with the promise of inclusion.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (6 times in verses 1-8)
Pay attention to the emotional tone: hopeful and inclusive, especially the phrase 'I will bring ... to My holy mountain'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being included, WHAT they must do, WHERE this happens, and WHY God is doing this.
tips: Include the groups: foreigners and eunuchs
Note the requirement: keep the Sabbath and hold fast the covenant
Describe the location: God's house (temple) and His holy mountain

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the promise to eunuchs (v. 4), the foreigner's fear (v. 3), or the temple becoming a 'house of prayer for all peoples' (v. 7).
tips: The phrase 'monument and a name better than sons and daughters' shows God's honor for eunuchs beyond typical social status
The foreigner's fear of separation is addressed by God's promise of inclusion
The temple becoming a 'house of prayer for all peoples' is a radical inclusion that contrasts with the temple's traditional Jewish exclusivity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is calling Judah to embrace foreigners and eunuchs as part of God's people, showing that God's salvation is for all who obey and keep the Sabbath
This prophecy points to a future where the temple will be inclusive, reflecting God's universal love and the coming of the Messiah who will gather all nations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'eunuch' in ancient context, the meaning of 'foreigner', and the requirement of 'keeping the Sabbath' for outsiders.
tips: Eunuchs in ancient Israel were often in positions of honor, but God's promise here is about spiritual inclusion beyond social status
Foreigners here likely refers to non-Israelites who have made a covenant with God
Keeping the Sabbath is a sign of covenant obedience, not just a ritual for Israelites; God is extending this to all who follow Him

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a 'house of prayer' for someone from a different background this week?
tips: Consider how you can be a place of blessing for those who are marginalized in your life or community
Reflect on an area where you might be excluding others (like in your church or community) and how you can extend the invitation of God's table to them

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise of inclusion. Ask for courage to welcome foreigners and eunuchs.

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 58:1-14 aloud, focusing on the contrast between hypocritical fasting (v.3-4) and true fasting (v.6-14).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Why have we fasted...' in verses 3-4
Pay attention to the contrast: 'You seek your own pleasure' (v.4) vs. 'loose the bonds of wickedness' (v.6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Judah) is being addressed, WHAT (their hypocritical fasting and the call for true fasting), WHERE (in the land of Judah), and WHY (to correct their empty rituals and promote justice).
tips: Include the people of Judah as the audience
Note that they are fasting but oppressing workers (v.4)
Highlight the contrast: they seek to please God but their actions are unjust (v.6-7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to 'loose the bonds of wickedness' (v.6), sharing bread with the hungry (v.7), or turning away from the Sabbath (v.13).
tips: The image of 'loosing bonds' (v.6) shows active release of oppression, not just ritual
Sharing bread with the hungry (v.7) is a tangible act of compassion that breaks the cycle of poverty
Turning back from the Sabbath (v.13) reflects the cultural practice of rest and worship as a sign of true devotion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage about the nature of true worship and fasting?
tips: Isaiah is challenging the people of Judah to move from ritualistic fasting to justice and compassion
He emphasizes that true fasting must involve freeing the oppressed and feeding the hungry (v.6-7) rather than self-punishment
This passage also points to the coming of the Messiah who will fulfill these justice demands

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'true fasting', the cultural context of fasting in Judah, and the connection to Christ.
tips: In ancient Israel, fasting was a common practice for repentance, but Isaiah critiques the hypocrisy of the people who fasted but oppressed others
The phrase 'turn back your foot from the Sabbath' (v.13) refers to the cultural practice of the Sabbath being a day of rest and worship, but the people were using it for work
The 'light breaking forth' (v.8) is a metaphor for the coming of the Messiah who will bring salvation and justice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'sharing bread with the hungry' (v.7) and ask: How can you practically share resources with someone in need this week?
tips: Identify one person who is hungry or in need of food this week
Plan to share a meal with them or donate food to a local food bank
Reflect on how your actions of sharing can be a sign of true fasting and justice

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His call to justice and compassion. Ask for the strength to live as a true fast (v.6-7) and to share with those in need.
tips: Thank God for the promise of light breaking forth (v.8) in your life through the Messiah
Pray for the courage to turn away from the Sabbath (v.13) and to honor God in your rest
Ask for the grace to share your resources with the hungry and homeless

chapters.chapterTitle: Arise, Shine, for Your Light Has Come

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 60:1-22 aloud, focusing on the repeated phrase 'arise, shine' and the contrast between darkness and light.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'light' (appears 5 times in the chapter)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from darkness (v2) to the rising glory (v3)
The phrase 'your light has come' is a call to action

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Judah) is being addressed, WHAT (the light of the LORD has come and the glory has risen), WHERE (the land of Judah), and WHY (the LORD has prepared a light for the nations).
tips: Include that the nations will come to the light of Judah (v5-7)
Note the coming of the LORD's glory (v3)
The purpose is to show that Judah is now the light for the nations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to 'arise, shine' (v1), the nations coming (v5-7), or the promise of the LORD as everlasting light (v20).
tips: The phrase 'arise, shine' is a joyful call to action that breaks the darkness
The image of the nations bringing wealth (gold and frankincense) from the east (v10) is a direct reference to the Magi and Christ
The promise that the LORD will be the everlasting light (v20) is a promise of Christ that never fades

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage? (Hint: This passage is a vision of the future glory of Judah under the Messiah.)
tips: Isaiah is telling Judah that the LORD has sent His light (Christ) to them, and they are now to be the light for the nations
This passage foreshadows the New Jerusalem where the LORD will be the light (Revelation 21:23)
The purpose is to encourage Judah in the midst of exile to see hope in the coming of the Messiah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast of darkness and light? The role of Judah as the light for the nations? The meaning of 'everlasting light'?
tips: The 'darkness' in v2 refers to the current state of Judah under Babylonian exile, but the light of Christ has come to them
The 'wealth of the nations' (v11) is a vision of the nations bringing gifts to Judah, which is a sign of the coming of the Messiah and the global church
The phrase 'everlasting light' (v20) refers to Christ, who is the light that never fades (John 8:12)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a place of light for others this week, as described in Isaiah 60:10-11?
tips: When you see people from other cultures or nations, be a place of welcome and light
Spend time with people from different backgrounds to share the hope of Christ
Pray for the nations to come to the light of Christ through you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His light that has come through Christ, and ask for the courage to be a place of light for others.
tips: Thank God that He is the everlasting light (v20) for His people
Pray for the nations to come to the light of Christ through you
Ask God to help you be a place of light and welcome for others this week

chapters.chapterTitle: The Year of the LORD's Favor

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 61:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between 'ashes' and 'beauty' in verses 3-4.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (v.1, v.3, v.6)
Pay attention to the contrast in verse 3: 'beautiful headdress instead of ashes, oil of gladness instead of mourning'
The phrase 'year of the LORD's favor' appears in verse 1

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the anointed one is, WHAT he brings, WHERE it happens, and WHY it matters to Judah.
tips: The anointed one is the speaker (the Messiah)
He brings liberty to captives and comfort to the brokenhearted
It happens in Judah (Zion) and is a response to God's covenant

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast in verse 3 (beauty for ashes), the promise of the 'garments of salvation' (v.10), or the 'year of the LORD's favor' (v.1)?
tips: The transformation from ashes (death) to beauty (life) is a powerful symbol of God's renewal
The 'garments of salvation' (v.10) represents the new spiritual identity in Christ
The 'year of the LORD's favor' (v.1) is a time of God's active blessing for the people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is promising restoration and hope for Judah after their suffering
The anointed one (the Messiah) will bring liberation and joy to the oppressed
This passage is a prophecy of the New Covenant and the coming of the Messiah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'year of the LORD's favor', the 'day of vengeance', or the 'garments of salvation'?
tips: The 'year of the LORD's favor' is not a fiscal year but a time of God's special blessing for the people
The 'day of vengeance' refers to God's judgment on the enemies of Judah, not general wrath
The 'garments of salvation' is a metaphor for the new spiritual state and the covering of sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you bring the 'beauty for ashes' to someone who is mourning this week?
tips: When you feel broken, ask God to give you the 'oil of gladness' (joy) instead of mourning
Share the message of liberty with someone who is oppressed or in chains
Pray for the 'year of the LORD's favor' to come to your life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of the 'year of the LORD's favor' and ask for the strength to bring beauty to ashes.
tips: Thank God for the restoration He brings to the broken
Ask for the courage to be a bringer of liberty to others
Pray for the 'garments of salvation' to cover you and others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 62:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'My Delight Is in Her' (v.5), 'Married' (v.5), and 'the mouth of the LORD will give' (v.5).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you shall be called' (v.5) emphasizing the new identity
Pay attention to the contrast between 'Forsaken' and 'My Delight Is in Her' (v.4-5)
Listen for the emotional shift from desolation to joy in the marriage metaphor (v.5-6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God declares to Zion, WHAT he will do for her, WHERE this restoration happens, and WHY he does it (based on God's love).
tips: Include the new name given by God (v.5)
Note that Zion is no longer called 'forsaken' or 'desolate' (v.4)
Mention the marriage imagery (v.5-6) as the reason for the new identity

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the new name (v.5), the marriage metaphor (v.5-6), or the promise of God's delight (v.5).
tips: The phrase 'My Delight Is in Her' (v.5) shows God's personal affection for Zion, which is a radical reversal of her past suffering
The marriage metaphor (v.5-6) is a powerful image of God's active love and the new covenant relationship
The promise that 'your sons shall marry you' (v.5) shows the generational restoration and continuity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage? Focus on the new identity and restoration of Zion.
tips: This passage is a response to Judah's exile and suffering, promising a restoration where they are no longer forsaken
The new name and marriage imagery show that God's love for Zion is a covenant that outlasts the exile
This prophecy points to the ultimate restoration in Christ, where the church becomes the new Zion

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The new name, the marriage metaphor, or the promise of God's delight in Zion?
tips: The phrase 'My Delight Is in Her' (v.5) is a new name that God gives to Zion, but it's not a human name; it's a declaration of God's heart
The marriage metaphor (v.5-6) is unusual because in the Old Testament, God is the bridegroom and the people are the bride (e.g., Hosea), but here it's Zion that is the bride
The phrase 'the mouth of the LORD will give' (v.5) means God will personally declare the new name, not a human authority

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you embody the new name of 'My Delight Is in Her' in your life this week? Focus on one area where God has restored you.
tips: Think about how you were 'forsaken' in the past and how Christ has restored you (v.4)
Pray for God to call you 'My Delight Is in Her' through Christ (v.5)
Share your new identity with one person this week as a sign of the restoration

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the new name and the marriage relationship. Ask for the delight of God in your life.
tips: Thank God for calling you 'My Delight Is in Her' through Christ
Pray for the courage to live as the bride of Christ in a world that often calls us forsaken
Ask God to help you share the joy of the new name with others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 63:1-14 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the Lord's red garments and His solitary action in the winepress.
tips: Notice the repeated 'I' as the active agent (e.g., 'I trod', 'I was appalled')
Pay attention to the phrase 'day of vengeance' (v. 1) and the blood imagery (v. 6)
The phrase 'crimsoned garments' (v. 1) symbolizes the blood of the nations

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the Lord is, WHAT He does, WHERE and WHEN this occurs, and WHY He acts this way.
tips: Include the Lord's solitary treading of the winepress (v. 4)
Note the blood of the nations spattered on His garments (v. 6)
The day of vengeance and the redemption that follows (v. 10-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Lord's red garments (v. 1), the winepress (v. 4), or the 'own arm' bringing salvation (v. 10)?
tips: The red garments symbolize the cost of judgment and the blood of the nations, showing the Lord's holiness and the consequence of rebellion
The phrase 'trod them in My anger and trampled them in My wrath' (v. 6) reveals the Lord's righteous anger against sin
The 'own arm' (v. 10) shows that salvation comes from God's own power, not human help

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah about the Lord's role in judgment and redemption?
tips: The passage addresses Judah's rebellion and the consequences (the day of vengeance) but also the Lord's ultimate salvation through His own power
This is a response to the current state of Judah (idolatry, rebellion) and foreshadows Christ's role as the one who treads the winepress alone
The Lord's sovereignty is emphasized: He acts alone in judgment and redemption

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'warrior from Edom', the 'winepress alone', and the 'day of vengeance'?
tips: The 'warrior from Edom' (v. 1) is a symbolic description of the Lord coming from the enemy's side (Edom) to execute judgment on the nations that have rebelled
The 'winepress alone' (v. 4) emphasizes that the Lord acts without human assistance in judgment, a contrast to the common practice of collective action
The 'day of vengeance' (v. 6) refers to a specific time when the Lord will judge the rebellious nations to fulfill His covenant with His people

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust the Lord's 'own arm' to save you when you feel isolated in your sin?
tips: When you face a situation where you feel like there's no one to help (like v. 10), pray for the Lord's strength to act on your behalf
Consider an area where you have rebelled against God and ask for the Lord to 'tread' the winepress (judgment) and then bring redemption
Practice surrendering to the Lord's 'arm' by sharing your burdens with Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the one who treads the winepress and brings redemption through His own power.
tips: Thank God for the blood of the nations (v. 6) that shows His judgment on sin
Ask for the strength of the Lord's 'own arm' (v. 10) to save you from your sins
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you not rebel and to be saved by the Lord's presence

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 64:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the plea for mercy and the repeated phrase 'we have all become like...' (v.6).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'we' in the prayer (v.4, v.6, v.13)
Pay attention to the phrase 'filthy rags' (v.6) which conveys deep sinfulness
The plea 'Be not so terribly angry' (v.24) is the emotional climax

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praying, WHAT they are asking for, WHERE this prayer takes place (in the context of Judah), and WHY they are making this plea.
tips: The people of Judah are the ones praying (v.4, v.6)
They are asking God to be merciful because they have sinned and are unclean (v.6)
This prayer takes place in the context of Judah's rebellion and the judgment that has come (v.1-3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of uncleanliness (v.6), the plea for mercy (v.24), or the metaphor of clay and potter (v.8)?
tips: 'We have all become like one who is unclean' (v.6) - this is a powerful image of universal sin
'We are the clay, and You are our potter' (v.8) - this shows God's sovereignty over our lives
The emotional plea 'Be not so terribly angry, O LORD' (v.24) - this is a cry for mercy in the face of God's wrath

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is emphasizing that Judah's sin has made them unclean and that they need God's mercy, not their own efforts
He is reminding them that God is the potter and they are clay, so they are in His hands and He can restore them
This passage is a prayer for mercy in the context of Judah's failure to keep God's covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'eye has not seen' (v.4), the concept of 'filthy rags' (v.6), or the expression of God's anger (v.2)?
tips: 'Eye has not seen' (v.4) refers to the fact that no human has ever seen God in the same way as the people of Judah have seen Him through His works
'Filthy rags' (v.6) is a metaphor for the state of the people being so sinful that they are beyond redemption without God's intervention
The expression of God's anger (v.2) is a direct response to Judah's sin, but the passage also shows that God is willing to be merciful

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This passage is a prayer for mercy. What situation this week requires you to pray for God's mercy, like the people of Judah in this passage?
tips: Consider an area where you feel like you are 'unclean' (v.6) and need God's mercy
How can you practice the humility of being 'clay' in God's hands (v.8) this week?
Pray for God to be merciful when you feel like you have sinned and are beyond repair

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and ask for Him to be less angry with us, as the people of Judah prayed.
tips: Thank God for being the potter who can transform us (v.8)
Pray for the strength to be like the clay that can be reshaped by God
Ask God to help us not be 'filthy rags' but to be clean in His sight

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 65:17-25 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the old and new creation in verses 18-25.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I create' (v.18, 21) emphasizing God's active role
Pay attention to the phrase 'no more shall be heard in it the sound of weeping' (v.21) for emotional tone

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is transformed, WHAT God does, WHERE this transformation occurs, and WHY this is happening.
tips: Include the contrast between the current rebellious nation and the new creation
Note the promise of Jerusalem becoming a joy (v.19)
Describe the end of suffering and the restoration of peace

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the creation of new heavens and earth (v.18), the wolf and lamb feeding together (v.25), or the removal of weeping (v.21)?
tips: The phrase 'the wolf and the lamb shall feed together' (v.25) is a powerful image of universal peace
The promise that 'no more shall be heard in it the sound of weeping' (v.21) brings hope for the end of suffering
The declaration 'I create new heavens and a new earth' (v.18) emphasizes God's sovereignty in creation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah is promising a future restoration for Judah after their rebellion
This passage emphasizes God's sovereignty in creating a new creation that is free from sin and suffering
The new creation is a response to Judah's past disobedience and a sign of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'new heavens and earth', the 'lamb and wolf' imagery, or the removal of weeping?
tips: The phrase 'new heavens and earth' (v.18) refers to complete renewal, not a physical new world but a spiritual transformation
The 'wolf and lamb' imagery (v.25) is a typical apocalyptic sign of peace but requires faith to understand
The removal of weeping (v.21) promises the end of suffering from sin and death, but it is a future event

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of hope in the new creation. What can you do this week to live in anticipation of God's future restoration?
tips: Practice gratitude for the new creation that is coming
Share the hope of the new earth with someone who is suffering
Avoid the old ways of life that cause pain and suffering

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the new creation and ask for His peace to come.
tips: Thank God for the promise of a world without suffering
Pray for the courage to live in hope while waiting for the new creation
Ask God to help us be instruments of peace in the current world

chapters.chapterTitle: The LORD's Final Judgment and Glory

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Isaiah 66:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the LORD's throne and human rebellion.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Heaven is My throne' (v.1) - emphasizes God's transcendence
Pay attention to the description of the humble and contrite spirit (v.2)
Listen for the metaphor of 'before she was in labor she gave birth' (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO the LORD is working with, WHAT He is doing, WHERE it happens, and WHY it matters for Judah.
tips: Include the contrast between the LORD's throne (heaven) and Judah's attempt to build a temple
Note the specific call to the humble and contrite in spirit (v.2)
Mention the sudden birth of Zion (v.7-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast of the humble (v.2), the sudden birth of Zion (v.7), or the LORD's coming in fire (v.17)?
tips: The phrase 'Before she was in labor she gave birth' (v.7) - a powerful metaphor for the sudden, miraculous birth of the true Israel
The comparison 'He who slaughters an ox is like one who kills a man' (v.4) - shows the moral corruption of Judah
The declaration 'The LORD will come in fire' (v.17) - the final judgment that will be both devastating and purifying

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Isaiah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Isaiah warns that Judah's religious rituals are meaningless without true humility and obedience
He promises the LORD will judge the rebellious but also bring a new Israel (Zion) born in one day
The contrast shows God's glory is beyond human attempts to build temples

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'the nation born in one day', the meaning of 'the humble and contrite spirit', or the 'eternal fire'?
tips: 'Born in one day' (v.7) refers to the sudden, divine birth of the true Israel (not a physical birth)
'The humble and contrite spirit' (v.2) is a deep spiritual condition of repentance, not just outward humility
'Eternal fire' (v.24) refers to the final judgment that will last forever (as opposed to temporary punishment)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the promise of the LORD's coming in fire and the birth of Zion (v.7) apply to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on what it means to be 'humble and contrite' (v.2) in your current circumstances
Consider how the LORD is 'bringing forth' a new community in your life through the Holy Spirit
Practice surrendering to God's timing, as the birth of Zion happens suddenly

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the LORD's final judgment and the birth of Zion (the true Israel)
tips: Thank God for His glory and for the new birth of Zion
Ask for the humility and contrition to be present in your heart
Pray for the courage to face the fire of judgment with hope
